{{Agriculture}} '''Agricultural engineering''' is the [[engineering]] discipline that studies [[agriculture|agricultural]] production and processing. Agricultural engineering combines the disciplines of [[mechanical engineering|mechanical]], [[civil engineering|civil]], [[electrical engineering|electrical]] and [[chemical engineering|chemical]] engineering principles with a knowledge of agricultural principles according to technological principles. A key goal of this discipline is to improve the efficacy and sustainability of agricultural practices.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.asabe.org/|title=ASABE|website=www.asabe.org|language=en-us|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref> One of the leading organizations in this industry is the [[American Society of Agricultural and Biological Engineering]].<ref name=":0" />
== ASABE standards == The ASABE provides safety and regulatory standards for the agricultural industry. These [http://www.asabe.org/standards/asabe-international-standards-activities.aspx#tabBody2177 standards] and regulations are developed on an international scale and include topics on fertilizers, soil conditions, fisheries, biofuels, biogass, feed machinery, tractors, and machinery.<ref name=":0" />
==Specialties== Agricultural engineers may engage in any of the following areas: * design of [[agricultural machinery]], equipment, and agricultural [[structures]] * [[internal combustion engines]] as applied to agricultural machinery * agricultural resource management (including [[land use]] and [[water use]]) * water management, conservation, and storage for crop [[irrigation]] and [[livestock]] production * [[surveying]] and land profiling * [[climatology]] and [[atmospheric science]] * [[soil]] management and conservation, including [[erosion]] and erosion control * [[seed]]ing, [[tillage]], [[harvesting]], and [[Process (engineering)|processing]] of [[crop]]s * [[livestock]] production, including [[poultry]], [[aquaculture|fish]], and [[dairy]] animals * [[waste management]], including animal waste, agricultural residues, and fertilizer runoff * [[food engineering]] and the processing of agricultural products * basic principles of [[circuit analysis]], as applied to electrical motors * physical and chemical properties of materials used in, or produced by, agricultural production * [[bioresource engineering]], which uses machines on the molecular level to help the environment. * [[Design of experiments]] related to crop and animal production
== History == The first curriculum in agricultural engineering was established at [[Iowa State University]] by Professor J. B. Davidson in 1903. The American Society of Agricultural Engineers, now known as the [[American Society of Agricultural and Biological Engineers]], was founded in 1907.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.asabe.org/about.html |title=ASABE website |accessdate=May 15, 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090514152850/http://www.asabe.org/about.html | archivedate= 14 May 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> A full history of events directly and indirectly influenced by agricultural engineering, see [http://www.asabe.org/about-us/history/timelines.aspx here].
== Agricultural engineers ==
Agricultural engineers may perform tasks such as planning, supervising and managing the building of dairy effluent schemes, [[irrigation]], [[drainage]], [[flood]] water control systems, performing [[environmental impact assessment]]s, [[agricultural]] [[Product (business)|product]] [[Process (engineering)|processing]] and interpret research results and implement relevant practices. A large percentage of agricultural engineers work in academia or for government agencies such as the [[United States Department of Agriculture]] or state [[agricultural extension]] services. Some are consultants, employed by private engineering firms, while others work in industry, for manufacturers of agricultural machinery, equipment, processing technology, and structures for housing livestock and storing crops. Agricultural engineers work in production, sales, [[management]], [[research]] and development, or [[applied science]].
In the United Kingdom the term Agricultural Engineer is often also used to describe a person that repairs or modifies agricultural equipment.
==Academic programs in agricultural and bio-systems engineering== Below is a listing of known academic programs that offer bachelor's degrees (B.S. or B.S.E. or B.E / B.Tech) in what [[ABET]] terms "[[Agricultural Engineering]]", "[[Biological systems engineering|Biosystems Engineering]]", "[[Biological Engineering]]", or similarly named programs. ABET accredits college and university programs in the disciplines of applied science, computing, engineering, and engineering technology.

{{EncelGeo-Crater |name=Al-Haddar |picture=[[Image:Dunyazad, Shahrazad, Al-Haddar.jpg|250px]]
Al-Haddar crater (top) as seen
by the ''Cassini'' spacecraft on March 9, 2005 |location={{Coord|50.54|N|200.64|W|globe:enceladus|notes=}} |diameter=15 km |depth= |discoverer=''[[Voyager 2]]'' |naming=Al-Haddar; The barber's second brother in "The Hunchback’s Tale" }} '''Al-Haddar''' is an [[impact crater]] on [[Saturn]]'s moon [[Enceladus (moon)|Enceladus]], first discovered by the [[Voyager program|Voyager]] spacecraft. It is named after Al-Haddar, one of the barber's six brothers in "[[The Hunchback's Tale]]" from ''[[The Book of One Thousand and One Nights]]''. Al-Haddar is located at 50.5° North [[Latitude]], 200.6° West [[Longitude]] and is approximately 14 kilometers across. It is the northernmost and smallest crater of a prominent crater triplet on Enceladus' anti-Saturnian hemisphere (there is no evidence that the impacts are related or were formed from break-up of a single body, like [[Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9|Shoemaker-Levy 9]]). ''[[Voyager 2]]'' observations of Al-Haddar revealed a bowl-shaped, simple crater, compared to its larger, more complex southern neighbors, [[Shahrazad (crater)|Shahrazad]] and [[Dunyazad (crater)|Dunyazad]] craters. The crater was mostly in shadow during the [[Cassini-Huygens Mission|''Cassini'' Spacecraft's]] close flyby on March 9, 2005, but numerous tectonic fractures were observed along its northern rim. ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{Gpn|14224|Al-Haddar}} {{cite web |title=Shahrazad (Se-4) |work=PIA12783: The Enceladus Atlas |publisher=NASA / Cassini Imaging Team |url=http://photojournal.jpl.nasa.gov/figures/PIA12783_full_5.jpg |accessdate=2012-02-04}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Al-Haddar (Crater)}} [[Category:Impact craters on Enceladus]] {{crater-stub}}

{{Orphan|date=August 2016}} {{Spanish name|'''Mencía'''|'''Ripley'''}}
'''Aída Teresa Mencía Ripley'''<ref name=COD>{{cite news|title=Juramentan deportistas en el comité apoyo al olimpismo|url=http://www.hoy.com.do/juramentan-deportistas-en-el-comite-apoyo-al-olimpismo/|accessdate=8 July 2016|publisher=Hoy|date=10 March 2010|language=Spanish}}</ref> is a [[biomedical scientist|scientist]] and [[clinical psychologist]] from the [[Dominican Republic]]. She is [[UNESCO Chairs|UNESCO Chair]] on Social and Academic Inclusion for People with Disabilities and Special Education Needs and Dean of Academic Research at the [[Universidad Iberoamericana (UNIBE)|Iberoamerican University of the Dominican Republic (UNIBE)]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Cátedra Unesco para las personas con discapacidad|url=http://www.listindiario.com/la-vida/2014/1/20/307616/Catedra-Unesco-para-las-personas-con-discapacidad|accessdate=8 July 2016|publisher=Listín Diario|date=21 January 2014|location=Santo Domingo|language=Spanish}}</ref>
She was born in [[Santo Domingo]] and raised in New York. She is the daughter of Aída Ripley Gómez (the daughter of Dominican hall of fame sportsman [[Enrique Ripley Marín]] and Aída Gómez Rueda <ref>{{cite news|last1=Peña|first1=Carlos|title=Sepultan a Enrique Ripley Marín; Resaltan cualidades y virtudes|url=http://elnacional.com.do/sepultan-enrique-ripley-marin-resaltan-cualidades-y-virtudes/|accessdate=8 July 2016|publisher=El Nacional|date=21 July 2009|language=Spanish|location=Santo Domingo}}</ref>) and Rafael Mencía Ochoa.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mencía|first1=Rafael|title=A Don Enrique Ripley, hombre que no reposa. Inmemoriam|url=http://www.listindiario.com/puntos-de-vista/2009/7/22/109029/A-Don-Enrique-Ripley-hombre-que-no-reposa-Inmemoriam|publisher=Listín Diario|accessdate=8 July 2016|archiveurl= |archivedate= |language=Spanish|date=23 July 2009}}</ref> She is the niece of artist Geo Ripley. Her paternal grandfather was Dominican diplomat [[Rafael Mencía Lister]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cidh.oas.org/countryrep/Rep.Dom.65eng/chap.5.htm|title=Chapter V - Dominican Republic 1965|publisher=Inter-American Commission on Human Rights}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.inesdyc.edu.do/sobre-el-inesdyc/historia|title=Historia|publisher=INESDyC}}</ref>
Mencía-Ripley graduated ''[[Summa Cum Laude]]'' from [[St. John's University (New York City)|St. John's University]] with a B.A. in psychology and earned an M.A. from the Graduate Faculty of the [[The New School|New School for Social Research]]. She later earned an M.A. and a Ph.D. from [[St. John's University (New York City)|St. John´s University]]. She is a member of the [[American Psychological Association]], [[WPATH]], The [[Interamerican Psychology Society]], and the Young Scientist Chapter of the Dominican Academy of Sciences.<ref name="UNIBE" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.academiadecienciasrd.org/noticias/346-presentaci%25C3%25B3n-de-la-publicaci%25C3%25B3n-j%25C3%25B3venes-cient%25C3%25ADficas-un-futuro-brillante-para-la-am%25C3%25A9ricas%25E2%2580%258F.html|title=Presentación de la publicación. Jóvenes Científicas: Un Futuro Brillante para La Américas|last=Administrador|website=www.academiadecienciasrd.org|access-date=2016-08-10}}</ref> She is also a member of the ''Comité Dominicano Barón Pierre de Coubertin''.<ref name="COD" />
Her main areas of research are gender and health, clinical psychology, psychometrics, and psychology of language.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.elcaribe.com.do/2016/03/09/presentaran-obra-sobre-jovenes-sobresalientes-ciencia|title=Presentarán obra sobre jóvenes sobresalientes en la ciencia|website=El Caribe|access-date=2016-08-10}}</ref> She is an advocate for inclusive education in the Dominican Republic<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://noticias.universia.com.do/en-portada/noticia/2014/04/11/1094794/primer-estudio-clinico-psico-social-ninos-paralisis.html|title=Primer Estudio Clínico Psico-Social en niños con parálisis|last=noticias.universia.com.do|access-date=2016-08-10}}</ref> and deals with issues related to ethical and culturally respectful research in developing countries that pay special attention to intersectional issues of gender, ethnicity, and disability <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://enfoquesocial.gob.do/noticias/vicepresidencia-busca-optimizar-pol%C3%ADticas-p%C3%BAblicas-para-reducir-pobreza/|title=OPSD - Observatorio de Políticas Sociales y Desarrollo|last=okler.net|website=enfoquesocial.gob.do|access-date=2017-08-25}}</ref>. As Dean of Research at UNIBE, she has steered initiatives that led to the creation of several research laboratories<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.laboratoriosunion.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=66:cibo-unibe-y-laboratorios-union-impulsan-proyectos-de-investigacion-unibe&catid=14:noticias&Itemid=214|title=CIBO-UNIBE y Laboratorios UNION impulsan proyectos de investigación {{!}} UNIBE|last=Grafico|first=Departamento|website=www.laboratoriosunion.com|access-date=2016-08-10}}</ref> and international agreements to foster scientific research in the Dominican Republic <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.international.uqam.ca/pages/detailNouvelle.aspx?id=1025|title=UQAM {{!}} International {{!}}|website=www.international.uqam.ca|access-date=2017-08-25}}</ref>. She is the 2017 winner of the José Salazar Award for best research paper in the Revista Interamericana de Psicología <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.listindiario.com/la-vida/2017/08/25/479678/cientifica-de-rd-obtiene-premio|title=Científica de RD obtiene premio|last=Diario|first=Listin|date=2017-08-25|work=listindiario.com|access-date=2017-08-25|language=es}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://eldia.com.do/cientifica-de-rd-gana-premio-internacional/|title=Científica de RD gana premio internacional|date=2017-08-24|work=El Día|access-date=2017-08-25|language=es-ES}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://elnuevodiario.com.do/cientifica-rd-gana-premio-internacional/|title=Científica de RD gana premio internacional|date=2017-08-23|work=El Nuevo Diario|access-date=2017-08-25|language=es-ES}}</ref>
==Works and publications== Some publications of Mencía Ripley are:<ref name="UNIBE">{{cite web|title=Dra. Aída Mencía Ripley, Ph.D.|url=http://www.unibe.edu.do/es/perfil/aida-mencia-ripley-phd|publisher=UNIBE|accessdate=8 July 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160708235129/http://unibe.edu.do/es/perfil/aida-mencia-ripley-phd|archivedate=8 July 2016|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mencía-Ripley|first=Aída Teresa|last2=Caminero|first2=Yira Vargas|date=2014-05-01|title=Abuso de sustancias en estudiantes universitarios dominicanos|url=http://revistas.uv.mx/index.php/REMSyS/article/view/1123|journal=Revista Electrónica Medicina, Salud y Sociedad|language=es|volume=4|issue=3}}</ref>
*Brondolo, E., Wellington, R., Brady, N., Mencía-Ripley, A., Thompson, S., Cassells, A., et al. (2006). Racism and coping in a community sample of Black and Latino(a) adults. ''Annals of Behavioral Medicine, 31'', S162. *Denton, E., Mencía-Ripley, A., Ullah, J., Brondolo, E., Cassells, A., Cubbin, C. & Tobin, J. (2005). Demographic variations in exposure to ethnicity-related maltreatment. ''Annals of Behavioral Medicine, 29'', S136. *Brondolo, E., Grantham, K., Karlin, W., Taravella, J., Mencía Ripley, A., Schwartz, J.E., et al. (2009). Trait hostility and ambulatory blood pressure among traffic enforcement agents: The effects of stressful social interactions. ''Journal of Occupational Health Psychology, 14'', 110-121. *Mencía Ripley, A. & Guerrero Martínez, S. (2012). Características de los pacientes con trastornos relacionados al abuso de sustancias en un hospital dominicano. ''Revista Electrónica Medicina, Salud y Sociedad, 2 (3)''. *Mencía Ripley, A., Fernández Melo, J., Mora, L., McDermutt, W., Thurston-Snoha, B., & Romero, P. (2012). Pilot study of a translation and cultural adaptation of the Anger Disorders Scale: Short Version. ''Humanities and Social Sciences Review, 1(4)'', 219-225. *Mencía-Ripley, A. & Vargas Caminero, Y. (2014). Abuso de sustancias en estudiantes universitarios dominicanos. ''Revista Electrónica Medicina, Salud y Sociedad, 4 (3)''. *Mencía-Ripley, A., Schwartz, J., & Brondolo, E. (2015). Gender identity, interpersonal interactions, and ambulatory blood pressure. ''Interamerican Psychology Journal, 49 (2)'', 261-271. *Thomas, T.M., Schanche Hodge, F., Kotkin-Jaszi, S., & Mencía-Ripley, A. (2016). Stress and coping among college students in the Dominican Republic.''Californian Journal of Health Promotion, 15 (1), 78-84''.

{{for|the movement within psychology from the 1910s to 1960s|Behaviorism}} {{for|the journal|Systems Research and Behavioral Science}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2016}}
'''Behavioural sciences''' explore the cognitive processes within [[organism]]s and the behavioural interactions between organisms in the natural world. It involves the systematic analysis and investigation of [[human]] and [[animal]] behavior through the study of the past, controlled and [[naturalistic observation]] of the present, and disciplined scientific [[experimentation]] and [[Conceptual model|modeling]]. It attempts to accomplish legitimate, objective conclusions through rigorous formulations and observation.<ref name= "Klemke">Klemke, E. D., Hollinger, R., and Kline, A. D., (1980), Introduction to the book in 'Introductory Readings in the Philosophy of Science': Buffalo, New York, Prometheus Books p 11-12</ref> Examples of behavioral sciences include [[psychology]], [[psychobiology]], [[anthropology]], and [[cognitive science]]. Generally, behavior science deals primarily with human action and often seeks to generalize about human behavior as it relates to society.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/behavioral+science|title=Definition of BEHAVIOURAL SCIENCE|author=|date=|website=www.merriam-webster.com|accessdate=19 March 2018}}</ref>
==Categories== Behavioural sciences includes two broad categories: neural — ''Information sciences'' and social — ''Relational sciences''.
Information processing sciences deals with [[information processing]] of stimuli from the social environment by cognitive entities in order to engage in decision making, social judgment and social perception for individual functioning and survival of organism in a social environment. These include [[psychology]], [[cognitive science]], [[psychobiology]], [[biological neural network|neural networks]], [[social cognition]], [[social psychology]], [[semantic networks]], [[ethology]], and [[social neuroscience]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/behavioral-sciences.html|title=What are behavioral sciences? definition and meaning|website=BusinessDictionary.com|access-date=23 December 2017}}</ref>
On the other hand, Relational sciences deals with relationships, interaction, communication networks, associations and relational strategies or dynamics between organisms or cognitive entities in a social system. These include fields like [[Social psychology (sociology)|sociological social psychology]], [[social networks]], [[dynamic network analysis]], [[agent-based model]] and [[microsimulation]].
==Applications== Insights from several pure disciplines across behavioural sciences are explored by various applied disciplines and practiced in the context of everyday life and business. These applied disciplines of behavioural science include: [[organizational behavior]], [[operations research]], [[consumer behaviour]] and [[media psychology]].
== Differentiation from social sciences == The term ''behavioural sciences'' is often confused with the term ''[[social sciences]]''.{{Who|date=September 2018}} Though these two broad areas are interrelated and study systematic processes of behaviour, they differ on their level of scientific analysis of various dimensions of behaviour.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/behavioral+science%3E|title=Definition of BEHAVIOURAL SCIENCE|website=www.Merriam-Webster.com|access-date=23 December 2017}}</ref>
Behavioural sciences abstract empirical data to investigate the decision processes and communication strategies within and between organisms in a social system. This involves fields like psychology, [[social neuroscience]] ethology, and cognitive science. In contrast, social sciences provide a perceptive framework to study the processes of a social system through impacts of social organization on structural adjustment of the individual and of groups. They typically include fields like [[sociology]], [[economics]], [[public health]], [[anthropology]], [[demography]] and [[political science]].<ref name="Klemke" />
Many subfields of these disciplines cross the boundaries between behavioral and social sciences. For example, [[political psychology]] and [[behavioral economics]] use behavioural approaches, despite the predominant focus on systemic and institutional factors in the broader fields of political science and economics.
==See also== {{Portal|Psychology|Science}} * [[Behaviour]] ** [[Human behaviour]] * [[List of academic disciplines]] * Science ** [[Fields of science]] *** [[Natural science]]s *** [[Social science]]s ** [[History of science]] ** [[History of technology]]

Kerlinger |title=Behavioural Research: A Conceptual Approach |place=New York |publisher=Holt, Rinehart & Winston |isbn=0-03-013331-9}} * E.D. Klemke, R. Hollinger & A.D. Kline, (eds.) (1980). ''Introductory Readings in the [[Philosophy of Science]]''. Prometheus Books, New York. *[[Neil J. Smelser]] & [[Paul B. Baltes]], eds. (2001). ''[[International Encyclopedia of the Social & Behavioral Sciences]]'', 26 v. Oxford: Elsevier. {{ISBN|978-0-08-043076-8}}

{{Unreferenced|date=September 2010}} {{Infobox University |name = |image = Technical Research Centre for Dependency Care and Autonomous Living logo.png |established = 2003 |type = Public |medical director = Antoni Yuste |attached director = Andreu Català |city = Vilanova i la Geltrú, [[Barcelona]] |country = [[Spain]] |website = www.upc.edu/cetpd [http://www.upc.edu/cetpd] }} The '''Technical Research Centre for Dependency Care and Autonomous Living''' (CETpD) is an applied research and technology transfer centre created for the [[Polytechnic University of Catalonia|Universitat Politèncica de Catalunya]] and the ''Fundació Hospital Comarcal Sant Antoni Abat'' on behalf of the ''Consorci de Servei a les Persones'' de Vilanova i la Geltrú, with the aim of covering the demand for research and development in the field of [[Gerontechnology]], [[Ambient intelligence|Ambient Intelligence]], Assistive [[Robotics]] and [[usability|User Experience Technologies]]. The CETpD carried out important applied research work and innovation on socially relevant developments, especially on technologies and systems designed to enhance independent living of elderly and disabled people. == Areas == === Ambient Intelligence === [[Ambient intelligence|Ambient Intelligence]] (AmI) implies an environment of distributed computing systems, unobstrusive and often invisible, with user friendly interfaces capable of learning and adapting to the particular needs of the users. CETpD AmI projects are included in the [[assistive technology|assistance]] field mainly for housing and health application. We are looking for technological solutions that have the potential to include everyone, that are affordable and build trust and confidence directed to improve the quality of life of any person specially elders and disabled. === Assistive Robotics === The priority lines of work are three:
* To develop new architectures of control and forms of signal processing which the robots allow to capture knowledge and being cognitive through the [[human-machine interaction]].
* To research in the more suitable forms of [[interaction]], so they are motivating and satisfying for the [[user (computing)|user]].
* To develop in an effective way [[robotic]] systems that are capable of supplying with personalised individual [[assistive technology|assistance]] to people with dependence (permanent, rehabilitation or convalescence). Therefore, the research implies areas like HRI, control and systems of [[machine learning|computational learning]] in complex, changing and uncertain environments, integrating processes of [[perception]], representation and [[interaction]] with people.
=== Usability === The purpose of the user experience field, [[usability]], is to provide relevant information about users expectations, capabilities and preferences, in order to ensure that products and services would meet end users -and other stakeholders- functional and affective needs. All the CETpD projects incorporates user's experience feedback in the process of contextual product and services development. === Balance, Gaits and Falls === Gait alterations, balance alterations and falls are major causes of [[disability]] in the elderly population. Such pathologies seriously impair elders' quality of life; furthermore, their consequences have high economic and social impact. Therefore, clinical and epedimiological studies on these pathologies are conducted at the CETpD in order to gain insight into their causes and to find novel therapeutics. === Gerontechnology === A major objective in geriatrics is to maintain elderly persons' independence to carry out their daily life activities and to interact with their environment. In this regard, [[technology]] may be an essential tool to facilitate elderly persons' [[autonomy]]. At the CETpD, they develop [[technology]] aimed to their environment, as well as remote diagnosis devices designed for early detection of health alterations in frail persons or persons living alone. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.upc.edu/cetpd CETpD web site] * [https://www.youtube.com/user/CETpD CETpD youtube channel] * [http://www.upc.edu UPC web site] * [http://www.fhcsaa.cat/ Fundació Hospital Comarcal Sant Antoni Abat web site] [[Category:Software engineering organizations]] [[Category:Computer science education]] [[Category:Gerontology organisations]] [[Category:Robotics organizations]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Carolyn Porco | image = Carolyn-porco-2016.jpg | image_size = 180px | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|3|6|}} | birth_place = [[Bronx]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | residence = | siblings = Dominic Porco, Elliot Porco, Rick Porco | citizenship = | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | ethnicity = | fields = [[Planetary science]]
[[Imaging science]] | workplaces = [[Space Science Institute|Cassini Imaging Central Laboratory for Operations]], [[University of Colorado at Boulder]] | alma_mater = [[California Institute of Technology]]
[[Stony Brook University]] | doctoral_advisor = [[Peter Goldreich]] | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = Leader of [[Cassini–Huygens|Cassini]] Imaging Team; Discoveries about [[Saturn]] system ; Member of [[Voyager program|Voyager]] Imaging Team; Expert in [[Planetary rings]] and [[Enceladus (moon)|Enceladus]]; [[The Day the Earth Smiled]]; Science communicator & public speaker; Film consultant | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[7231 Porco|Porco asteroid]]; [[Lennart Nilsson Award]] (2009); AAS [[Carl Sagan Medal]] (2010); Caltech Distinguished Alumni Award (2011); [[Time magazine|Time]] 25 Most Influential People in Space (2012) | signature = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''Carolyn C. Porco''' (born March 6, 1953) is an American [[Planetary science|planetary scientist]] who explores the outer [[solar system]], beginning with her imaging work on the [[Voyager program|Voyager]] missions to [[Jupiter]], [[Saturn]], [[Uranus]] and [[Neptune]] in the 1980s. She led the imaging science team on the ''[[Cassini–Huygens|Cassini]]'' mission in orbit around Saturn and September 15, 2017 when Cassini was de-orbited to burn up in Saturn's upper atmosphere.{{cite web |title=Cassini Solstice Mission: Team Members |url=http://saturn.jpl.nasa.gov/mission/team/ |publisher=[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory|JPL]] |accessdate=2013-04-03 }} She is an expert on planetary rings and the Saturnian moon, [[Enceladus (moon)|Enceladus]]. She has co-authored more than 110 scientific papers on subjects ranging from the [[spectroscopy]] of Uranus and Neptune, the interstellar medium, the [[Photometry (astronomy)|photometry]] of planetary rings, satellite/ring interactions, computer simulations of planetary rings, the thermal balance of [[Triton (moon)|Triton's]] polar caps, heat flow in the interior of Jupiter, and a suite of results on the atmosphere, satellites, and rings of Saturn from the ''Cassini'' imaging experiment.{{cite web |title=Cassini Imaging Team Science Results |url=http://ciclops.org/sci/index.php |publisher=[[CICLOPS]] |accessdate=2012-01-06 }} In 2013, Cassini data{{cite journal |last1=Hedman |first1=M. M. |last2=Nicholson |first2=P. D. |year=2013 |title=Kronoseismology: Using density waves in Saturn's C ring to probe the planet's interior |journal=[[The Astronomical Journal]] |volume=146 |issue=1 |pages=12 |arxiv=1304.3735 |bibcode=2013AJ....146...12H |doi=10.1088/0004-6256/146/1/12 }} confirmed a 1993 prediction{{cite journal |last1=Marley |first1=M. S. |last2=Porco |first2=C. C. |title=Planetary Acoustic Mode Seismology: Saturn's Rings |journal=[[Icarus (journal)|Icarus]] |year=1993 |volume=106 |issue=2 |pages=508–524 |bibcode=1993Icar..106..508M |doi=10.1006/icar.1993.1189 }} by Porco and Mark Marley that acoustic oscillations within the body of Saturn are responsible for creating particular features in the rings of Saturn. Porco was founder of [[The Day the Earth Smiled]]. She was also responsible for the epitaph and proposal to honor the late renowned planetary geologist [[Eugene Shoemaker]] by sending his [[cremains]] to the [[Moon]] aboard the [[Lunar Prospector]] spacecraft in 1998.{{cite web |last=Porco |first=C. C. |date=February 2000 |title=Destination Moon |url=http://www.astronomy.com/~/media/Files/PDF/Magazine%20articles/Destination%20Moon.pdf |work=[[Astronomy (magazine)|Astronomy]] |pages=52–55 }}{{cite web |last=Porco |first=C. C. |date=April 13, 2006 |title=Eugene M. Shoemaker: A Tribute |url=http://ciclops.org/public/tribute.html |publisher=[[CICLOPS]] |accessdate=2012-01-06 }} A frequent public speaker, Porco has given two popular lectures at TED{{cite web |last=Porco |first=C. C. |date=March 2007 |title=This is Saturn |url=http://www.ted.com/talks/carolyn_porco_flies_us_to_saturn.html |publisher=[[TED (conference)|TED]] |accessdate=2012-01-06 }}{{cite web |last=Porco |first=C. C. |date=February 2009 |title=Could a Saturn Moon Harbor Life? |url=http://www.ted.com/talks/carolyn_porco_could_a_saturn_moon_harbor_life.html |publisher=[[TED (conference)|TED]] |accessdate=2012-01-06 }} as well as the opening speech for [[Pangea day|Pangea Day]], a May 2008 global broadcast coordinated from six cities around the world, in which she described the cosmic context for human existence.{{cite web |date=May 10, 2008 |title=Pangea Day Intro |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=suQrWrr5T1M |publisher=[[YouTube]] |accessdate=2012-01-06 }} Porco has also won a number of awards and honors for her contributions to science and the public sphere; for instance, in 2009, ''[[New Statesman]]'' named her as one of 'The 50 People Who Matter Today.'{{cite web |date=September 24, 2009 |title=The 50 people who matter today: 31-40 |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/life-and-society/2009/09/world-energy-power-list-mackay |work=[[New Statesman]] |accessdate=2012-01-06 }} In 2010 she was awarded the [[Carl Sagan Medal]], presented by the [[American Astronomical Society]] for Excellence in the Communication of Science to the Public.{{cite web |title=Cassini Imaging Leader Honored With American Astronomical Society Carl Sagan Award |url=http://www.ciclops.org/news/special_news_052810_1.php?js=1 |publisher=[[CICLOPS]] |accessdate=2013-08-22 }} And in 2012, she was named one of the 25 most influential people in space by ''[[Time magazine|Time]]'' magazine.{{cite news |last=Bjerklie |first=D. |date=Fall 2012 |title=The 25 Most Influential People in Space |url=http://www.amesteam.arc.nasa.gov/NewsArticles/TIME_Space_Allamandola_25MostInfluentialPeopleinSpace.pdf |work=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]] |pages=88–99 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515121347/http://www.amesteam.arc.nasa.gov/NewsArticles/TIME_Space_Allamandola_25MostInfluentialPeopleinSpace.pdf |archivedate=May 15, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} == Education == Porco was born in New York City. She graduated in 1970 from [[Cardinal Spellman High School (New York City)|Cardinal Spellman High School]] in [[the Bronx]], in New York City. She earned a BS degree from the [[State University of New York at Stony Brook]] in 1974. She received her Ph.D in 1983 from the [[California Institute of Technology]] in the Division of Geological and Planetary Sciences.{{cite web|url=http://caltechcampuspubs.library.caltech.edu/2491/1/June_10%2C_1983.pdf |title=Caltech Commencement Program |date=1983-06-10 |publisher=Caltech Campus Publications |accessdate=2013-03-29}} Supervised by dynamicist [[Peter Goldreich]], she wrote her doctoral dissertation focused on Voyager discoveries in the rings of Saturn. == Career == === Voyager === In the fall of 1983, Dr. Porco joined the faculty of the Department of Planetary Sciences at the [[University of Arizona]]; the same year she was made a member of the [[Voyager program|Voyager]] Imaging Team. In the latter capacity, she was an active participant in the ''[[Voyager 2]]'' encounters with [[Uranus]] in 1986 and [[Neptune]] in 1989, leading the Rings Working Group within the Voyager Imaging Team during the Neptune encounter. As a young Voyager scientist, she was the first person to describe the behavior of the eccentric ringlets and the "spokes" discovered by Voyager within the rings of Saturn; to elucidate the mechanism by which the outer Uranian rings were being shepherded by the Voyager-discovered moons [[Cordelia (moon)|Cordelia]] and [[Ophelia (moon)|Ophelia]]; and to provide an explanation for the shepherding of the rings arcs of Neptune by the moon [[Galatea (moon)|Galatea]], also discovered by Voyager. She was a co-originator of the idea to take a 'portrait of the planets' with the ''[[Voyager 1]]'' spacecraft, and participated in the planning, design, and execution of those images in 1990, including the famous ''[[Pale Blue Dot]]'' image of Earth.{{cite book |last=Sagan |first=C. |year=1997 |title=Pale Blue Dot: A Vision of the Human Future in Space |publisher=[[Ballantine Books]] |isbn=978-0-345-37659-6 }} === ''Cassini–Huygens'' === In November 1990, Porco was selected as the leader of the Imaging Team for the [[Cassini–Huygens mission|''Cassini-Huygens'' mission]], an international mission that successfully placed a spacecraft in orbit around Saturn and deployed the atmospheric ''Huygens'' probe to Saturn's largest satellite, Titan. She is also the Director of the Cassini Imaging Central Laboratory for Operations (CICLOPS), which was the center of uplink and downlink operations for the ''Cassini'' imaging science experiment and the place where ''Cassini'' images are processed for release to the public. CICLOPS is part of the [[Space Science Institute]] in [[Boulder, Colorado]]. In the course of the ongoing mission, Porco and her team have discovered seven moons of Saturn: [[Methone (moon)|Methone]] and [[Pallene (moon)|Pallene]],{{cite journal |last=Porco |first=C. C. |year=2004 |url=http://www.cbat.eps.harvard.edu/iauc/08300/08389.html#Item1 |title=S/2004 S 1 and S/2004 S 2 |journal=[[IAU Circular]] |volume=8389 |page=1 |bibcode=2004IAUC.8389....1P |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120327152805/http://www.cbat.eps.harvard.edu/iauc/08300/08389.html |archivedate=March 27, 2012 |df=mdy }} [[Polydeuces (moon)|Polydeuces]],{{cite journal |last=Porco |first=C. C. |year=2004 |url=http://www.cbat.eps.harvard.edu/iauc/08400/08432.html |title=Satellites and Rings of Saturn |journal=[[IAU Circular]] |volume=8432 |page=1 |bibcode=2004IAUC.8432....1P }} [[Daphnis (moon)|Daphnis]],{{cite journal |last=Porco |first=C. C. |year=2004 |url=http://www.cbat.eps.harvard.edu/iauc/08500/08524.html |title=S/2005 S 1 |journal=[[IAU Circular]] |volume=8524 |page=1 |bibcode=2004IAUC.8524....1P |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120327152936/http://www.cbat.eps.harvard.edu/iauc/08500/08524.html |archivedate=March 27, 2012 |df=mdy }} [[Anthe (moon)|Anthe]],{{cite journal |last=Porco |first=C. C. |year=2007 |url=http://www.cbat.eps.harvard.edu/iauc/08800/08857.html |title=S/2007 S 4 |journal=[[IAU Circular]] |volume=8857 |page=1 |bibcode=2007IAUC.8857....2P }} [[Aegaeon (moon)|Aegaeon]],{{cite journal |last=Porco |first=C. C. |year=2009 |title=S/2008 S 1 |journal=[[IAU Circular]] |volume=9023 |page=1 |bibcode=2009IAUC.9023....1P }} and a small moonlet in the outer B ring.{{cite journal |last=Porco |first=C. C. |year=2009 |title=S/2009 S 1 |journal=[[IAU Circular]] |volume=9091 |page=1 |bibcode=2009IAUC.9091....1P }} They also found several new rings, such as rings coincident with the orbits of [[Atlas (moon)|Atlas]], [[Janus (moon)|Janus]] and [[Epimetheus (moon)|Epimetheus]] (the Saturnian 'co-orbitals') and Pallene; a diffuse ring between Atlas and the [[F Ring|F ring]]; and new rings within several of the gaps in Saturn's rings.{{cite journal |last=Porco |first=C. C. |year= |title=Cassini Imaging Science: Initial Results on Saturn's Rings and Small Satellites |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |volume=307 |issue=5713 |pages=1226–1236 |arxiv= |bibcode= 2005Sci...307.1226P |doi=10.1126/science.1108056 |pmid=15731439 |date=February 2005 }} In 2013, ''Cassini'' data confirmed a 1993 prediction by Porco and Mark Marley that acoustic oscillations within the body of Saturn are responsible for creating particular features in the rings of Saturn. This confirmation, the first to demonstrate that planetary rings can act like a seismograph in recording oscillatory motions within the host planet, should provide new constraints on the interior structure of Saturn. Such oscillations are known to exist in the sun{{cite journal |last=Hiremath |first=K. M. |year=2012 |title=Seismology of the Sun: Inference of Thermal, Dynamic and Magnetic Field Structures of the Interior |class= |arxiv=1210.0467 |doi=10.1007/978-3-642-38167-6_19 |journal=Springer Series on Atomic, Optical, and Plasma Physics |pages=317–341 }} as well as other stars.{{cite web |date=March 26, 1996 |title=Asteroseismology |url=http://www.noao.edu/noao/song/seismo.html |publisher=[[National Optical Astronomy Observatory]] |accessdate=2013-05-07 }} Porco's team was responsible for the first sighting of a hydrocarbon lake, as well as a lake district, in the south polar region of [[Titan (moon)|Titan]] in June 2005.{{cite web |date=June 28, 2005 |title=Land of Lakes? |url=http://ciclops.org/view.php?id=1161 |publisher=[[CICLOPS]] |accessdate=2012-01-06 }} (A group of similar – and larger – features were sighted in the north polar region in February 2007.){{cite web |date=March 17, 2007 |title=Exploring the Wetlands of Titan |url=http://ciclops.org/view.php?id=2631 |publisher=[[CICLOPS]] |accessdate=2012-01-06 }} The possibility that these sea-sized features are either completely or partially filled with liquid hydrocarbons is significantly strengthened by subsequent observations by other ''Cassini'' instruments.{{cite web |last=Di Justo |first=P. |date=March 28, 2007 |title=Meet Carolyn Porco, the Scientist Who Made Saturn a Rock Star |url=https://www.wired.com/science/space/news/2007/03/nasa_qa |journal=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |accessdate=2013-08-22 }} Her team was also responsible for the first sighting of plumes erupting from [[Enceladus (moon)|Enceladus]], Saturn's sixth largest moon. They first suggested, and provided detailed scientific arguments, that these jets might be geysers erupting from reservoirs of near-surface liquid water under the south pole of the small moon. === ''New Horizons'' === Porco was a member of the imaging team for the ''[[New Horizons]]'' mission to [[Pluto]] and the [[Kuiper Belt]] through 2014. The probe made its Pluto flyby in 2015. ===The Day the Earth Smiled=== {{See also|The Day the Earth Smiled}} As the ''Cassini'' imaging team lead, Porco initiated and planned the capture of a picture of Saturn with the Earth in the distance on July 19, 2013,{{cite web|title=The Day the Earth Smiled mosaic|url=http://www.ciclops.org/view/7699/The-Day-the-Earth-Smiled|accessdate=December 7, 2013}} an image along the lines of the famous ''Pale Blue Dot'' photo.{{cite news|last=Madrigal|first=Alexis|title=The Carl Sagan of Our Time Reprises the 'Pale Blue Dot' Photo of Earth|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2013/11/the-carl-sagan-of-our-time-reprises-the-pale-blue-dot-photo-of-earth/281414/|accessdate=December 7, 2013|newspaper=The Atlantic|date=November 12, 2013}} The taking of the image was part of a larger concept entitled [[The Day The Earth Smiled]], in which people the world over were invited to celebrate humanity's place in the cosmos and life on Earth by smiling the moment the picture was taken.{{cite web|title=The Day The Earth Smiled|url=http://thedaytheearthsmiled.com/info.php|accessdate=July 2, 2013}} === University positions === Porco served in the faculty of the University of Arizona from 1983 to 2001, achieving tenured professorship in 1991. She taught both graduates and undergraduates and was one of five finalists for the University of Arizona Honors Center ''Five Star Faculty Award'', a campus-wide student-nominated, student-judged award for outstanding undergraduate teaching. Porco is a Senior Research Scientist at the Space Science Institute in Boulder, Colorado, and she is an Adjunct Professor at the [[University of Colorado at Boulder]]. === NASA advisor === Porco has been an active participant in guiding the American planetary exploration program through membership on many important [[NASA]] advisory committees, including the Solar System Exploration Subcommittee, the Mars Observer Recovery Study Team, and the Solar System Road Map Development Team. In the mid-1990s, she served as the chairperson for a small NASA advisory working group to study and develop future outer solar system missions and she served as the Vice Chairperson of the Steering Group for the first Solar System Decadal Survey, sponsored by NASA and the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]]. === Public speaking === Porco speaks frequently on the ''Cassini'' mission and planetary exploration in general, and has appeared at renowned conferences such as PopTech 2005{{cite web |url=http://www.poptech.org/people/carolyn_porco |title=Carolyn Porco |work=PopTech: People |publisher=PopTech |location=Brooklyn, New York, United States |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120626100235/http://poptech.org/people/carolyn_porco# |archivedate=June 26, 2012 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=2013-02-23 |df=mdy-all }} and [[TED (conference)|TED]] (2007, 2009). She attended and was a speaker at the [[Beyond Belief: Science, Religion, Reason and Survival|Beyond Belief]] symposium on November 2006.{{cite web|url=http://thesciencenetwork.org/programs/beyond-belief-science-religion-reason-and-survival#tab3 |title=Beyond Belief 2006: Science, Religion, Reason and Survival |publisher=Thesciencenetwork.org |date= |accessdate=2012-01-06}}[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/21/science/21belief.html A Free-for-All on Science and Religion], ''The New York Times'', November 21, 2006. Porco's 2007 TED talk, "The Human Journey," detailed two major areas of discovery made by the ''Cassini'' mission: the exploration of the Saturnian moons Titan and Enceladus. In her introductory remarks, Porco explained: {{Quote|So the journey back to Saturn is really part of, and is also a metaphor for, a much larger human voyage.}} In describing the environment of Titan, with its molecular [[nitrogen]] atmosphere suffused with organic compounds, Porco invited her audience to imagine the scene on the moon's surface: {{Quote|Stop and think for a minute. Try to imagine what the surface of Titan might look like. It's dark: high noon on Titan is as dark as deep Earth twilight on the Earth. It's cold, it's eerie, it's misty, it might be raining, and you are standing on the shores of [[Lake Michigan]] brimming with [[paint thinner]]. That is the view that we had of the surface of Titan before we got there with ''Cassini''. And I can tell you that what we have found on Titan, though not the same in detail, is every bit as fascinating as that story is, and for us, for ''Cassini'' people, it has been like a [[Jules Verne]] adventure come true.}} After describing various features discovered on Titan by ''Cassini'', and presenting the historic first photograph of Titan's surface by the ''Huygens'' lander, Porco went on to describe Enceladus and the jets of "fine icy particles" which erupt from the moon's southern pole: {{Quote|...we have arrived at the conclusion that these jets may, they may, be erupting from pockets of liquid water near, under the surface of Enceladus. So we have, possibly, liquid water, organic materials and excess heat. In other words we have possibly stumbled upon the [[holy grail]] of modern-day planetary exploration, or in other words an environment that is potentially suitable for living organisms. And I don't think I need to tell you that the discovery of life elsewhere in our Solar system, whether it be on Enceladus or elsewhere, would have enormous cultural and scientific implications. Because if we could demonstrate that [[Abiogenesis|genesis]] had occurred – not once but twice, independently, in our Solar system – then that means by inference it has occurred a staggering number of times throughout our Universe in its 13.7 billion year history.}} Porco's 2009 TED Talk was "Could a Saturn moon harbor life?". She was a speaker at the 2016 [[Reason Rally]].{{cite web|url=http://reasonrally.org/speakers/|title=Speakers|author=|date=September 4, 2015|work=[[Reason Rally]]|accessdate=February 19, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170314221134/http://reasonrally.org/speakers/|archivedate=March 14, 2017|df=mdy-all}} === Television and film === Porco has been a regular [[CNN]] guest analyst and consultant on astronomy, has made many radio and television appearances explaining science to the lay audience, including appearances on the MacNeil/Lehrer ''Newshour'', [[CBS]]'s ''60 Minutes'', Peter Jennings's ''The Century'', and TV documentaries on planetary exploration such as ''The Planets'' on the [[Discovery Channel]] and the [[BBC]], ''A Traveler's Guide to the Planets'' on the [[National Geographic Channel]], ''Horizon'' on the BBC, and a Nova Cassini special on [[PBS]]. For the 2003 [[A&E Network|A&E]] special on the Voyager mission entitled ''Cosmic Journey: The Voyager Interstellar Mission and Message'', Porco appeared onscreen and also served as the show's science advisor and animation director. Porco served as an adviser for the film ''[[Contact (1997 American film)|Contact]]'' (1997), which was based on a novel by the well-known astronomer [[Carl Sagan]]. The actress [[Jodie Foster]] portrayed the heroine in the movie, and Sagan reportedly suggested that she use Porco as a real-life model to guide her performance.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/22/science/space/22prof.html|title=An Odyssey From the Bronx to Saturn's Rings | work=The New York Times | first=Dennis | last=Overbye | date=September 22, 2009 | accessdate=April 28, 2010}} Porco was also an adviser on the film ''[[Star Trek (film)|Star Trek]]'' (2009). The scene in which the ''Enterprise'' comes out of warp drive into the atmosphere of Titan, and rises submarine-style out of the haze, with Saturn and the rings in the background, was Porco's suggestion.{{cite web|last=Pascale|first=Anthony|title=Exclusive Interview With Carolyn Porco – Star Trek's New Science Advisor|url=http://trekmovie.com/2008/02/11/interview-with-star-treks-new-science-advisor/|work=TrekMovie.com|accessdate=April 3, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemaspy.ca/article.php?id=857 |title=Cinema Boffin Interview: Carolyn Porco Talks 'Star Trek XI' |author=[[Kevin Grazier]] |date=2008-04-27 |publisher=Cinema Boffin |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006055623/http://www.cinemaspy.ca/article.php?id=857 |archivedate=October 6, 2008 }} Porco was a guest on the BBC's ''[[Stargazing Live]]'' Series 4 in January 2014 === Interviews and articles === Porco has given numerous interviews in print media on subjects ranging from planetary exploration to the conflict between science and religion (for example, ''[[Newsweek]]''{{cite web|last=Adler|first=Jerry|title=The New Naysayers|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2006/09/10/the-new-naysayers.html|work=Newsweek|accessdate=April 3, 2013|date=September 10, 2006}}{{cite web|last=Adler|first=Jerry|title=Losing Our Religion|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2006/11/09/losing-our-religion.html|work=Newsweek|accessdate=April 3, 2013|date=November 9, 2006}} and the journal ''[[The Humanist]]''{{cite news |title= Science and Spirituality: An Interview With Carolyn Porco |volume= 68 |publisher=The Humanist |date= January–February 2008}}). She has been profiled many times in print, beginning in the ''[[Boston Globe]]'' (October 1989),{{cite web|last=Chandler|first=David L.|title=Seeking the Truth Amid the Rings|work=The Boston Globe|date=October 2, 1989}} ''[[The New York Times]]'' (August 1999, September 2009),{{cite web|last=Niethammer|first=Carolyn|title=Carolyn Porco: Cassini Scientist Yielded to the Seduction of Space|url=https://www.nytimes.com/library/national/science/081799sci-nasa-cassini-2.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=April 3, 2013}} the ''[[Tucson Citizen]]'' (2001),{{cite web|last=Tobin|first=Mitch|title=Cassini scientist leaving UA|url=http://tucsoncitizen.com/morgue2/2001/01/20/114451-cassini-scientist-leaving-ua/|work=Tucson Citizen|accessdate=April 3, 2013|date=January 2, 2001}} ''[[Newsday]]'' (June 2004), for the [[Royal Astronomical Society of Canada]] (2006), in ''[[Astronomy Now]]'' (2006), in ''[[Discover Magazine]]'' (2007),{{cite news |first= Maia |last= Weinstock |title= Planetary Paparazzo: Carolyn Porco |publisher=Discover Magazine's Unseen Universe |date= Winter 2007}} and also online on CNN.com (2005){{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2005/TECH/space/02/15/saturn.astronomer/index.html |title=Astronomer's 'cosmic connection' to Saturn |publisher=Cnn.com |date=2005-02-15 |accessdate=2012-01-06}} and Edge.org.{{cite web|url=http://www.edge.org/3rd_culture/bios/porco.html |title=Carolyn Porco profile on the Edge.org website |publisher=Edge.org |date= |accessdate=2012-01-06}} Prior to ''Cassini''{{’}}s launch, she was a strong and visible defendant of the usage of radioactive materials on the ''Cassini'' spacecraft. She is a supporter of a plan for human spaceflight toward the [[Moon]] and [[Mars]], and in an op-ed piece published in ''The New York Times'',{{cite news|last=Porco |first=Carolyn |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/20/opinion/20porco.html |title=NASA Goes Deep |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=2007-02-20 |accessdate=2012-01-06}} she highlighted the benefits of a deep-space-capable heavy launch vehicle for the robotic exploration of the solar system. Porco has advocated for prioritizing the exploration of [[Enceladus]] over [[Europa (moon)|Europa]].{{cite news |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2018/07/the-case-for-enceladus-as-the-best-place-to-look-for-life-beyond-earth/ |title=Senior scientist argues that we should bypass Europa for Enceladus |publisher=''[[Ars Technica]]'' |date=July 5, 2018 |first=Eric |last=Berger |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180705194616/https://arstechnica.com/science/2018/07/the-case-for-enceladus-as-the-best-place-to-look-for-life-beyond-earth/ |archive-date=July 5, 2018}} === Other === In 1994, Porco was a member of a committee (chaired by Carl Sagan) entitled "Public Communication of NASA's Science", and in 1999, she reviewed a biography of Sagan for ''[[The Guardian]]''.{{cite web|last=Porco|first=Carolyn|title=First reach for the stars|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/1999/nov/20/biography|work=The Guardian|accessdate=April 3, 2013|date=November 19, 1999}} Her popular science articles have been published in ''The Sunday Times'', ''[[Astronomy (magazine)|Astronomy]]'', the ''[[Arizona Daily Star]]'', ''[[Sky & Telescope]]'', ''[[American Scientist]]'', and ''[[Scientific American]]''. She is active in the presentation of science to the public as the leader of the Cassini Imaging Team, as the creator/editor of the website where ''Cassini'' images are posted. She writes the site's homepage "Captain's Log" greeting to the public.{{cite web|url=http://ciclops.org |title=Ciclops |publisher=Ciclops |date= |accessdate=2012-01-06}} She is an atheist.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_2d9x_qIZIMC&pg=PA160&lpg=PA160&dq=Carolyn%20Porco%20atheist&source=bl&ots=vWghx7r3PK&sig=FR9cToau-v1Axgcmt3ojD6K63Vc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi9ya-Kjb_OAhWH1R4KHY0sDME4MhDoAQg5MAY#v=onepage&q=Carolyn%20Porco%20atheist&f=false|title=Enlightenment Living|first=Ryan|last=Somma|date=July 1, 2010|publisher=Ryan Somma|pages=160–161|accessdate=February 19, 2017|via=Google Books}} She is also the CEO of [http://diamondskyproductions.com/ Diamond Sky Productions], a small company devoted to the scientific, as well as artful, use of planetary images and computer graphics for the presentation of science to the public. == Awards and honors == In 1999, Porco was selected by ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' (London) as one of 18 scientific leaders of the 21st century,{{cite news |first= Steve |last= Farrer |title= The brains behind the 21st century |work=The Sunday Times |page= 6 |location=UK |date= January 10, 1999}} and by ''Industry Week'' as one of 50 Stars to Watch.{{cite web|last=Pospisil|first=Vivian|title=50 R&D Stars to Watch|url=http://www.industryweek.com/emerging-technologies/50-rd-stars-watch|work=Industry Week|accessdate=April 3, 2013|date=December 21, 2004}} In 2008 she was chosen to be on ''[[Wired magazine|Wired]]'' magazine's inaugural 'Smart List: 15 People the Next President Should Listen To.'{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/politics/law/magazine/16-10/sl_intro |title=The 2008 Smart List: 15 People the Next President Should Listen To |publisher=[[Wired magazine|Wired]] magazine |date=September 22, 2008|accessdate=2012-10-21}} Her contributions to the exploration of the outer solar system were recognized with the naming of Asteroid [[7231 Porco|(7231) Porco]] which is "Named in honor of Carolyn C. Porco, a pioneer in the study of planetary ring systems...and a leader in spacecraft exploration of the outer solar system."{{cite web|author=Alan Chamberlin |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=7231;orb=1 |title=JPL Small-Body Database Browser |publisher=Ssd.jpl.nasa.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-01-06}} In 2008, Porco was awarded the [[Isaac Asimov Science Award]] by the [[American Humanist Association]].{{cite web|url=http://www.americanhumanist.org/press/CarolynPorco.php |title=Humanists to Honor Lead Imaging Scientist on the Cassini Saturn Project |publisher=Americanhumanist.org |date= |accessdate=2012-01-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080514115404/http://www.americanhumanist.org/press/CarolynPorco.php |archivedate=May 14, 2008 |df=mdy }} In September 2009, Porco was awarded The [[Huntington Library]]'s Science Writer Fellowship for 2010.{{cite web|url=http://diamondskyproductions.com/news/9-15-2009.php |title=Carolyn Porco Awarded Huntington Science Writer Fellowship |publisher=Diamondskyproductions.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224125120/http://diamondskyproductions.com/news/9-15-2009.php |archivedate=February 24, 2012 |df=mdy }} That same month, ''[[New Statesman]]'' named her as one of 'The 50 People Who Matter Today.' In October 2009, she and [[Babak Amin Tafreshi]] were each awarded the 2009 [[Lennart Nilsson Award]] in recognition of their photographic work. The award panel's citation for Dr. Porco reads as follows: {{quote|Carolyn Porco combines the finest techniques of planetary exploration and scientific research with aesthetic finesse and educational talent. While her images, which depict the heavenly bodies of the Saturn system with unique precision, serve as tools for the world's leading experts, they also reveal the beauty of the universe in a manner that is an inspiration to one and all.{{cite web |url=http://www.lennartnilssonaward.se/winner.php?id=47,48 |title=Lennart Nilsson Award |publisher=Lennartnilssonaward.se |date= |accessdate=2012-01-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090926234039/http://www.lennartnilssonaward.se/winner.php?id=47%2C48 |archivedate=September 26, 2009 |df=mdy }}}} In October 2010, Porco was awarded the 2010 [[Carl Sagan Medal]] for Excellence in the Communication of Science to the Public, presented by the American Astronomical Society's Division for Planetary Sciences. In May 2009, Porco received an [[Honorary Doctorate]] of Science from the State University of New York at Stony Brook,{{cite web|url=http://diamondskyproductions.com/news/5-21-2009.php |publisher=Cassini Imaging Central Laboratory for Operations (CICLOPS) |title=Cassini Imaging Leader Awarded Honorary Degree from Stony Brook University |date=2009-05-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710122751/http://diamondskyproductions.com/news/5-21-2009.php |archivedate=July 10, 2011 |df=mdy }} of which she is an [[alumna]]. And in 2011 she won the Distinguished Alumni Award from the California Institute of Technology, the highest honor regularly bestowed by Caltech.{{cite web |author=Kathy Svitil |url=http://media.caltech.edu/press_releases/13405 |title=Caltech Names Five Distinguished Alumni |publisher=Media.caltech.edu |date=2011-05-14 |accessdate=2012-01-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120126060816/http://media.caltech.edu/press_releases/13405 |archivedate=January 26, 2012 |df=mdy }} In 2012, Porco was named one of the 25 most influential people in space by ''[[Time magazine|Time]]'' magazine. == Musical interests == [[File:Cassini team Abbey road.jpg|thumb|300px|Porco (at right) re-enacting the famous Beatles photograph at [[Abbey Road (street)|Abbey Road]] with the other members of the Cassini Imaging Team.]] Porco is fascinated by the 1960s and [[The Beatles]] and has, at times, incorporated references to The Beatles and their music into her presentations, writings, and press releases. The first color image released by ''Cassini'' to the public was an image of Jupiter, taken during ''Cassini''{{’}}s approach to the giant planet and released on October 9, 2000 to honor [[John Lennon]]’s 60th birthday.{{cite web|url=http://ciclops.org/view.php?id=110 |title=Jupiter & Europa in True Color |publisher=Ciclops.org |date=2000-10-09 |accessdate=2012-01-06}} In 2006, she produced and directed a brief 8-minute movie of 64 of Cassini’s most spectacular images,{{cite web|url=http://ciclops.org/view.php?id=24 |title=Sixty-Four Scenes from Saturn … The Movie |publisher=Ciclops.org |date= |accessdate=2012-01-06}} put to the music of the Beatles, in honor of [[Paul McCartney]]’s 64th birthday. And in 2007, she produced a poster showing 64 scenes from Saturn.{{cite web|url=http://ciclops.org/view.php?id=2879 |title=Sixty-Four Scenes from Saturn … The Poster |publisher=Ciclops.org |date= |accessdate=2012-01-06}}{{cite web|url=http://ciclops.org/view.php?id=2914 |title=Sixty-Four Scenes from Saturn … The Images |publisher=Ciclops.org |date= |accessdate=2012-01-06}} Porco is also interested in dance and fascinated with [[Michael Jackson]]. In August 2010, she won a Michael Jackson costume/dance contest held in Boulder, Colorado.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.425046899386.206099.116163229386 |title=MJ Dance Party |publisher=Facebook.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-06}} Quotes of Porco's were used in the production of "The Poetry of Reality (An Anthem for Science)", "A Wave of Reason", "Children of Africa (The Story of Us)", and "Onward to the Edge!" by [[Symphony of Science]]. == References == {{reflist | colwidth = 30em | refs = {{cite journal| doi = 10.1126/science.1123013| last1 = Porco| first1 = C. C.| authorlink1 = Carolyn Porco| last2 = Helfenstein| first2 = P.| last3 = Thomas| first3 = P. C.| last4 = Ingersoll| first4 = A. P.| last5 = Wisdom| first5 = J.| last6 = West| first6 = R.| last7 = Neukum| first7 = G.| last8 = Denk| first8 = T.| last9 = Wagner| first9 = R.| date = 10 March 2006| title = Cassini Observes the Active South Pole of Enceladus| journal = Science| volume = 311| issue = 5766| pages = 1393–1401| pmid = 16527964| pmc = | bibcode = 2006Sci...311.1393P| ref = {{sfnRef|Porco Helfenstein et al. 2006}}}} }} == External links == {{Commons category}} * [http://carolynporco.com/ CarolynPorco.com] – Official website * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080428001237/http://www.pangeaday.org/filmDetail.php?id=24 Pangea Day opening speech by Carolyn Porco] * {{TED speaker}} ** [http://www.ted.com/talks/carolyn_porco_flies_us_to_saturn "This is Saturn" (TED2007)] ** [http://www.ted.com/talks/carolyn_porco_could_a_saturn_moon_harbor_life "Could a Saturn moon harbor life?" (TED2009)] * [http://www.itconversations.com/shows/detail767.html Podcast on the ''Cassini'' mission by Carolyn Porco] * [https://twitter.com/carolynporco Carolyn Porco Twitter page] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Porco, Carolyn}} [[Category:American atheists]] [[Category:American astronomers]] [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Planetary scientists]] [[Category:Women planetary scientists]] [[Category:Women astronomers]] [[Category:Voyager program]] [[Category:California Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:American people of Italian descent]] [[Category:University of Arizona faculty]] [[Category:Scientists from New York City]] [[Category:20th-century astronomers]] [[Category:21st-century astronomers]] [[Category:20th-century American scientists]] [[Category:21st-century American scientists]] [[Category:20th-century women scientists]] [[Category:21st-century women scientists]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Use Indian English|date=January 2016}} {{update|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox project | abbreviation = DBT | country = India | primeminister = [[Manmohan Singh]], [[Narendra Modi]] | ministry = Ministry of Petroleum & Natural Gas | launched = {{Start date and age|2013|01|01|df=y}} | current_status = Active j }} {{Politics of India}} '''Direct Benefit Transfer''' or '''DBT''' is an attempt to change the mechanism of transferring subsidies launched by [[Government of India]] on 1 January 2013. This program aims to transfer subsidies directly to the people through their bank accounts. It is hoped that crediting subsidies into bank accounts will reduce leakages, delays, etc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dbtmis.planningcommission.nic.in/dbtentry/homepage.aspx|title=DBT(DIRECT BENEFIT TRANSFER)|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=[[Rejaul Karim Laskar|Laskar]]|first1=R. K.|title=Direct cash transfer: A game changer move|url=http://old.thefinancialworld.com/epaper/fwepaper_new.aspx|accessdate=30 January 2018|agency=The Financial World|date=April 2, 2013}}</ref>
== Structure == The primary aim of this Direct Benefit Transfer program is to bring transparency and terminate pilferage from distribution of funds sponsored by Central Government of India. In DBT, benefit or subsidy will be directly transferred to citizens living below poverty line. [[Central Plan Scheme Monitoring System]] (CPSMS), being implemented by the Office of Controller General of Accounts, will act as the common platform for routing DBT. CPSMS can be used for the preparation of beneficiary list, digitally signing the same and processing of payments in the bank accounts of the beneficiary using the Aadhaar Payment Bridge of NPCI.<ref>[http://cpsms.nic.in/Users/LoginDetails/Login.aspx?ReturnUrl=%2fdefault.aspx Central Plan Scheme Monitoring System [CPSMS]<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> All relevant orders related with the DBT are available on the CPSMS website.
==History== The program was launched in selected cities of India on 1 January 2013.<ref name="The New Indian Express Direct Benefit Transfer to be launched today">{{cite news|title=Direct Benefit Transfer to be launctoday|url=http://newindianexpress.com/states/karnataka/article1402701.ece|accessdate=8 January 2013|newspaper=The New Indian Express|date=1 January 2013}}</ref><ref name="Govt to review benefits transfer project on Jan 15">{{cite news|title=Govt to review benefits transfer project on Jan 15|url=http://business-standard.com/india/news/govt-to-review-benefits-transfer-projectjan-15/498105/|accessdate=8 January 2013|newspaper=Business Standard}}</ref> It was launched in 20 districts, covering scholarships and social security pensions initially.
Former Union [[Ministry of Rural Development (India)|Minister for Rural Development]] of India [[Jairam Ramesh]] and former [[Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh]] [[N. Kiran Kumar Reddy]] inaugurated the scheme at Gollaprolu in East Godavari district on 6 January 2013.<ref name="Direct Benefit Transfer scheme finally gets going">{{cite news|title=Direct Benefit Transfer scheme finally gets going|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/direct-benefit-transfer-scheme-finally-gets-going/article4281371.ece|accessdate=8 January 2013|newspaper=The Hindu|location=Chennai, India|date=7 January 2013}}</ref> The government has decided to review the progress on regular basis.<ref name="Govt to review benefits transfer project on Jan 15" />
The first review was scheduled to be undertaken on 15 January 2013.<ref name="Govt to review benefits transfer project on Jan 15" /> According to [[P. Chidambaram]], former Union Minister of Finance of India, the scheme will be rolled out across 11 more districts by 1 February and 12 more districts by 1 March 2013.<ref name="Govt to review benefits transfer project on Jan 15" />
In April 2013 the government decided to extend the DBT scheme in 78 more districts of the country from July 1, 2013. The decision was taken by then Prime Minister Dr. Manmohan Singh after a review meeting.<ref name="DBT scheme to be extended in 78 new districts from July 1, 2013">{{cite news|title=DBT scheme to be extended in 78 new districts from July 1, 2013|url=http://www.myaadhaarcard.in/direct-cash-transfer/dbt-scheme-to-be-extended-in-78-new-districts-from-july-1-2013/}}</ref> The 78 new districts will include 6 districts each from Uttar Pradesh and Himachal Pradesh, 3 each from Bihar and Tamil Nadu, 2 from West Bengal and 4 each from Odisha and Gujarat.
In a review by the Prime Minister's Office on 5 August 2013, the minutes reported that two schemes dominated transfers through CPSMS - 83% of all transfers were for the [[Janani Suraksha Yojana]] and scholarships. Lack of computerized records for schemes to be linked to DBT was hindering rollout. The minutes show that out of 39.76 lakh beneficiaries who ought to have been covered under various schemes, only 56% had bank accounts, 25.3% had both bank accounts and aadhaar numbers, but only 9.62% have bank accounts seeded with aadhaar numbers.<ref>http://finmin.nic.in/dbt/record_dbt0508.pdf</ref>
==Programs part of DBT== * National Child Labour Project * Student Scholarship * LPG subsidy On June 1, 2013, the minister of Petroleum & Natural Gas, M [[Veerappa Moily]] formally launched the scheme direct benefit transfer for LPG (DBTL) Scheme in 20 high [[Aadhaar]] coverage districts. The subsidy on LPG cylinders will be credited directly to consumers' Aadhaar-linked bank accounts. All Aadhaar-linked domestic LPG consumers will get an advance in their bank account as soon as they book the first subsidized cylinder before delivery. On receiving the first subsidized cylinder subsidy for next will again get credited in their bank account, which can then be available for the purchase of the next cylinder at market rate until the cap of 12 cylinders per year is reached.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-06-01/news/39675093_1_lpg-cylinders-aadhaar-number-domestic-lpg-consumers | work=The Times Of India | title=Moily launches Direct Benefit Transfer Scheme for LPG in Karnataka | date=1 June 2013}}</ref>
Modified Version of DBTL Scheme : (November 2014) Government of India Introduced Modified Direct Benefit Transfer of LPG (DBTL) scheme in 54 districts in 11 states including all in Kerala starting November 15, 2014 whereby LPG consumers who have not yet availed the benefit will be able to get cash subsidy amount transferred into their accounts to buy Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) cylinders at market price.<ref name="Pahal DBTL-nov-27-14">{{cite web | url=http://www.pahaldbtlscheme.com/what-is-pahal-dbtl-scheme/ | title=Pahal 'DBTL' Scheme | publisher=www.pahaldbtlscheme.com/ | date=23 December 2014 | accessdate=23 December 2014 | author=pavan1804}}</ref>
74 Schemes of 17 ministries of central government were under DBT by 31 May 2016. As on Dec 2017,DBT has been implemented in 400 schemes from 46 ministries.<ref>{{citation |title=Aadhaar law will ensure Direct Benefit Transfer reaches genuine beneficiaries: FM Jaitley |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/money/report-aadhaar-law-will-ensure-direct-benefit-transfer-reaches-genuine-beneficiaries-fm-jaitley-2234747 |work=[[Daily News and Analysis]] |date=15 July 2016 }}</ref>
== See also == * [[Public Distribution System]] * [[Subsidies in India]] * [[Malnutrition in India]] * [[Central Plan Scheme Monitoring System]]
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.rdcalculator.co.in/steps-to-receive-subsidy-under-direct-benefit-transfer-of-lpg/ Modified DBTL Scheme 2014] * [http://www.allonmoney.com/save-money/pahal-dbtl-scheme-benefits-process/ PAHAL Scheme Benefits] * [http://www.getlpgsubsidy.in/ LPG Subsidy:PAHAL Registration]

{{No footnotes|date=April 2009}} [[George Heilmeier]] proposed the '''dynamic scattering effect''' which causes a strong scattering of light when the electric field applied to a special [[liquid crystal]] mixture exceeds a threshold value. A DSM cell requires the following ingredients:
* a liquid crystal with negative dielectric anisotropy (aligns the LC long axis perpendicular to the electric field), * [[homeotropic alignment]] of the LC (i.e. perpendicular to the substrate planes), * doping of the LC with a substance that increases the conductivity of the LC to allow a current to flow. With no voltage applied the LC-cell with the homeotropically aligned LC is clear and transparent. With increasing voltage and current, the electric field is trying to align the long molecular axis of the LC perpendicular to the field while the ion transport through the layer has the tendency to align the LC perpendicular to the substrate plates. As a result, a striped repetitive pattern is generated in the cell, of which the building blocks are named "Williams domains". Upon further increase of the voltage this regular pattern is replaced by a turbulent state which is strongly scattering light. This effect belongs to the class of electro-hydrodynamic effects in LCs. Electro-optic displays can be realized with that effect in the transmissive and reflective mode of operation. The driving voltages required for light scattering are in the range of several ten volts and the non-trivial current is depending on the area of the activated segments. The DMS effect was thus not suited for battery powered electronic devices. == References == * G. Heilmeier, L.A. Zanoni, and L. Barton, Proc. IEEE 56, 1162 (1968) * B. Bahadur, Liquid Crystals: Applications and Uses, World Scientific, 1990 [[Category:Liquid crystal displays]] {{physics-stub}}

The '''effective number of parties''' is a concept introduced by Laakso and Taagepera (1979) which provides for an adjusted number of [[political parties]] in a country's [[party system]]. The idea behind this measure is to count parties and, at the same time, to [[Weight function|weight]] the count by their relative strength. The relative strength refers to their vote share ("effective number of electoral parties") or seat share in the parliament ("effective number of parliamentary parties"). This measure is especially useful when comparing [[electoral system]]s across countries, as is done in the field of [[political science]].<ref>Lijphart, Arend (1999): Patterns of Democracy. New Haven/London: Yale UP</ref> The number of parties equals the effective number of parties only when all parties have equal strength. In any other case, the effective number of parties is lower than the actual number of parties. The effective number of parties is a frequent operationalization <!-- what does this word mean? --> for the fragmentation of a party system.
[[File:Effective Number of Parliamentary Parties in the Netherlands (1981-2017).png|thumb|Example of how the Effective Number of Parties shows the fragmentation of the Dutch political landscape (1981-2017)]]
There are two major alternatives to the effective number of parties-measure.<ref name="Lijphart1994">{{cite book|author=[[Arend Lijphart]] |title=Electoral Systems and Party Systems: A Study of Twenty-seven Democracies, 1945-1990 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hsz3ML3hgUUC&pg=PA69 |date=1 January 1994 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-827347-9 |page=69}}</ref> John K. Wildgen's index of "hyperfractionalization" accords special weight to small parties.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cps.sagepub.com/content/4/2/233.extract |title=The Measurement of Hyperfractionalization |publisher=Cps.sagepub.com |date=1971-07-01 |accessdate=2014-01-05}}</ref> Juan Molinar's index gives special weight to the largest party.<ref>{{cite journal|jstor=1963951|title=Counting the Number of Parties: An Alternative Index|first=Juan|last=Molinar|date=1 January 1991|publisher=|journal=The American Political Science Review|volume=85|issue=4|pages=1383–1391|doi=10.2307/1963951}}</ref> Dunleavy and Boucek provide a useful critique of the Molinar index.<ref>P. Dunleavy and F. Boucek (2003): 'Constructing the Number of Parties.' Party Politics 9(3): 291-315.</ref>
==Formulae== According to [[Markku Laakso|Laakso]] and [[Rein Taagepera|Taagepera]] (1979)<ref>Laakso, M.; R. Taagepera (1979): Effective Number of Parties: A Measure with Application to West Europe. ''Comparative Political Studies'' 12:3-27.</ref> the ''effective number of parties'' is computed by the following formula: {| |- | <math>N = \frac{1}{\sum_{i=1}^n p_i^2} </math> |} Where n is the number of parties with at least one vote/seat and <math> p_i^2 </math> the square of each party’s proportion of all votes or seats. The proportions need to be ''normalised'' such that, for example, 50 per cent is 0.5 and 1 per cent is 0.01. This is also the formula for the [[Simpson index|inverse Simpson index]], or the true diversity of order 2.
An alternative formula proposed by Golosov (2010)<ref>Golosov, Grigorii V. (2010): The Effective Number of Parties: A New Approach. ''Party Politics'' 16:171-192.</ref> is {| |- | <math>N = \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{p_i}{p_i+p_1^2-p_i^2} </math> |} which is equivalent - if we only consider parties with at least one vote/seat - to {| |- | <math>N = \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{1+(p_1^2/p_i)-p_i} </math> |}
Here, n is the number of parties, <math> p_i^2 </math> the square of each party’s proportion of all votes or seats, and <math> p_1^2 </math> is the square of the largest party’s proportion of all votes or seats.
==Values== The following table illustrates the difference between the values produced by the two formulas for eight hypothetical vote or seat constellations: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Constellation !! Largest component, fractional share !! Other components, fractional shares !! N, Laakso-Taagepera !! N, Golosov |- | A || 0.75 || 0.25 || 1.60 || 1.33 |- | B || 0.75 || 0.1, 15 at 0.01 || 1.74 || 1.42 |- | C || 0.55 || 0.45 || 1.98 || 1.82 |- | D || 0.55 || 3 at 0.1, 15 at 0.01 || 2.99 || 2.24 |- | E || 0.35 || 0.35, 0.3 || 2.99 || 2.90 |- | F || 0.35 || 5 at 0.1, 15 at 0.01 || 5.75 || 4.49 |- | G || 0.15 || 5 at 0.15, 0.1 || 6.90 || 6.89 |- | H || 0.15 || 7 at 0.1, 15 at 0.01 || 10.64 || 11.85 |}
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.tcd.ie/Political_Science/people/michael_gallagher/ElSystems/Docts/ElectionIndices.pdf Michael Gallagher providing data on the Laakso-Taagepera effective number of parties for over 900 elections in over 100 countries] * Average effective number of parties (Golosov) for 183 democratic party systems and non-systems, 1792-2009, reported in Golosov, Grigorii V., [http://ppq.sagepub.com/content/19/1/122.abstract "Towards a Classification of the World's Democratic Party Systems, Step 1: Identifying the Units"], Party Politics, Vol. 19, No. 1, January 2013, pp. 134–138. * [http://golosovpubs.ucoz.com/index/indices_of_the_effective_number_of_parties_and_party_system_nationalization_in_excel/0-13 How to compute Golosov’s effective number of parties in Excel]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Effective Number Of Parties}} [[Category:Electoral systems]] [[Category:Political science]] [[Category:Political party systems]]
