{{COI|date=March 2018}} [[File:Paul Willis - Australian Skeptics National Convention 2013.jpg|thumb|Willis speaking at the [[Australian Skeptics]] National Convention 2013]] '''Paul M. A. Willis''' is a [[Palaeontology|palaeontologist]], [[Science communication|science communicator]] and former Director of the [[Royal Institution of Australia]] (RiAus).
== Career == Willis studied [[zoology]] and [[geology]] at [[University of Sydney]] and went on to complete a PhD in [[palaeontology]] at the [[University of New South Wales]] .<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/profiles/content/s2109471.htm|title=Dr Paul Willis|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=ABC|access-date=}}</ref> He has been a resident palaeontologist on ten [[Antarctic]] expeditions and has written or co-authored eight books on [[dinosaur]]s, rocks and [[fossil]]s.
While Willis found his first fossil when he was six, the earliest part of his collection was a small echinoid collected by his parents on their honeymoon <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mediaengagementservices.com.au/single-post/2017/12/19/The-most-valuable-present}}</ref>. Willis completed a BSc at Sydney University in zoology and geology before conducting a PhD at the University of New South Wales. His Doctoral thesis was on The Phylogenetic Systematics of Australasian Crocodilians. Willis's doctoral studies resulted in the erection of several new taxa including the subfamily [[Mekosuchinae]], and the genera [[Baru]], [[Kambara]], [[Australosuchus]], [[Trilophosuchus]] and [[Harpacoshampsa]]. He conducted extensive field work, mostly in North Queensland, as well as completing a period as a paleontological Preparator at The [[Australian Museum]]. During this time Willis prepared an opalised skeleton dubbed by him as Eric the Plesiosaur and later named [[Umoonasaurus]].
In 1997, Willis commenced a traineeship with the ABC.<ref name=":0" /> During his career in public broadcasting, Willis went on to report and present stories for ''[[Quantum (TV series)|Quantum]]'' and ''Catalyst'' on [[ABC (Australian TV channel)|ABC]] and the series ''[[Monster Bug Wars]]'' on [[SBS (Australian TV channel)|SBS]]. Willis produced over 350 stories for ''Catalyst'' during a ten-year stint with the program. He left his employment at the ABC to take up directorship of the Royal Institution of Australia in 2011 which ended in July 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/catalyst/stories/3313575.htm|title=Catalyst: Farewell Dr Paul Willis - ABC TV Science|website=www.abc.net.au|access-date=2016-09-17}}</ref> He also worked for ABC radio, creating ''The Correx Files'' for [[Triple J]], presenting numerous regular science talkback segments on various radio stations across the country and contributing to ''The Science Show'', ''Earthbeat'' and ''The Health Report.''<ref name=":0" />.
Willis is now freelancing science communications through his company [https://www.mediaengagementservices.com.au Media Engagement Services] as well as conducting some paleontological studies as an Adjunct Associate Professor at Flinders University.
== Honours == In 2000 Willis was a joint recipient of the [[Eureka Prizes|Eureka Prize]] for Science Communication and was voted Australian Skeptic of the Year in 2002 for working to counter [[pseudoscience]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://riaus.org.au/people/paul-willis-director/|title=Paul Willis - Director - RiAusRiAus {{!}} Bringing science to people and people to science|website=riaus.org.au|access-date=2016-09-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |editor=Barry Williams| date= Summer 2002 |title=Skeptic of the Year |url=http://www.skeptics.com.au/wp-content/uploads/magazine/The%20Skeptic%20Volume%2022%20(2002)%20No%204.pdf |journal= The Skeptic |publisher= Australian Skeptics Inc. |volume=22 |issue=4 |page=12 |doi= |ISSN=0726-9897| access-date= }}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Use British English|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Richard Keith Ellis | image = | caption = Keith Ellis, at [[Fermilab]]. | birth_date = {{b-da|November 17, 1949}} | birth_place = [[Aberdeen]], [[UK]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = | residence = | known_for = [[Quantum chromodynamics]] [[Collider]] [[phenomenology (particle physics)|phenomenology]] | alma_mater = [[University of Oxford]]
[[New College, Oxford]]
[[Wadham College, Oxford]] | doctoral_advisors = [[Guido Altarelli]]
[[Luciano Maiani]] | doctoral_students = | work_institution = [[University of Durham]] | prizes = [[Sakurai Prize]] (2009)
[[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (2009) | footnotes = | website = {{URL|www.ippp.dur.ac.uk/profile/ellis}} }} '''Richard Keith Ellis''' (born November 17, 1949) is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[theoretical physicist]], at the [[University of Durham]] and a leading authority on perturbative [[Quantum Chromodynamics|quantum chromodynamics]] and collider phenomenology. ==Education== He graduated from the [[University of Oxford]] (MA 1971, D. Phil 1974). He has held positions at [[Imperial College]], [[MIT]], [[Caltech]], [[CERN]] and the [[Sapienza University of Rome|University of Rome]]. ==Career and research== He went to Fermilab in 1984. He was Head of the Theoretical Physics Department at [[Fermilab]] from 1993 to 2004. In 2015 he moved to the [[University of Durham]] in the UK, where he is a professor of Physics and Director of the [https://www.ippp.dur.ac.uk/ Institute for Particle Physics Phenomenology]. Ellis' work is of importance to the study of elementary particles at colliders, such as the Fermilab Tevatron, and the CERN [[Large Hadron Collider]]. Ellis has contributed in a substantial way to the interpretation of experiments performed at high energy. Together with Douglas Ross and Tony Terrano he performed the first calculation of jet structure in e+e- annihilation which allowed precise determination of the strong coupling. {{cite journal |author1=R.Keith Ellis |author2=D.A. Ross |author3=A.E. Terrano | title=The Perturbative Calculation of Jet Structure in e+ e- Annihilation | journal=Nuclear Physics | volume=B178 | issue=3 | pages=421–456 | year=1981 | doi=10.1016/0550-3213(81)90165-6|bibcode = 1981NuPhB.178..421E }} In addition, with Guido Altarelli and Guido Martinelli he performed a calculation of lepton pair production which allow reconciliation of observed rates with theoretical calculations.{{cite journal |author1=Guido Altarelli |author2=R.Keith Ellis |author3=G. Martinelli | title=Large Perturbative Corrections to the Drell-Yan Process in QCD | journal=Nuclear Physics| volume=B157 | pages=461–497 |issue=3 | year=1979 | doi=10.1016/0550-3213(79)90116-0|bibcode = 1979NuPhB.157..461A }} He has also co-authored a number of widely read papers on the theory of heavy quark production.{{cite journal |author1=P. Nason, S. Dawson |author2=R. Keith Ellis |lastauthoramp=yes | title=The Total Cross-Section for the Production of Heavy Quarks in Hadronic Collisions | journal=Nuclear Physics| volume=B303 | pages=607–633 | issue=4 | year=1988 | doi=10.1016/0550-3213(88)90422-1|bibcode = 1988NuPhB.303..607N }}{{cite journal |author1=P. Nason, S. Dawson |author2=R. Keith Ellis |lastauthoramp=yes | title=The One Particle Inclusive Differential Cross-Section for Heavy Quark Production in Hadronic Collisions | journal=Nuclear Physics| volume=B327 | pages=49–92 | issue=1 | year=1989 | doi=10.1016/0550-3213(89)90286-1|bibcode = 1989NuPhB.327...49N }}{{cite journal |author1=John C. Collins |author2=R. Keith Ellis |lastauthoramp=yes | title=Heavy quark production in very high-energy hadron collisions | journal=Nuclear Physics| volume=B360 | pages=3–30 | year=1991 | doi=10.1016/0550-3213(91)90288-9|bibcode = 1991NuPhB.360....3C }} He is also co-author for the parton-level Monte Carlo program MCFM.{{cite web|last1=Campbell|first1=John|last2=Ellis|first2=Keith|last3=Williams|first3=Ciaran|title=MCFM - Monte Carlo for FeMtobarn processes|url=http://mcfm.fnal.gov/|website=MCFM|publisher=Fermilab}} He is the coauthor with [[James Stirling (physicist)|W. J. Stirling]] and [[B. R. Webber]] of a book on QCD and collider physics [http://www.hep.phy.cam.ac.uk/theory/webber/QCDbook.html] published by Cambridge University Press in 1996.[https://inspirehep.net/author/profile/R.K.Ellis.1 Scientific publications of R. K. Ellis on [[INSPIRE-HEP]]] ==Honours and awards== Ellis was elected a Fellow of the [[American Physical Society]] in 1988 and a [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] of London in 2009. Also in 2009, Ellis together with [[John C. Collins|John Collins]] and [[Davison Soper]] won the [[Sakurai Prize|J. J. Sakurai Prize for Theoretical Particle Physics]], ''For work in perturbative Quantum Chromodynamics, including applications to problems pivotal to the interpretation of high energy particle collisions.'' [http://www.aps.org/units/dpf/awards/sakurai.cfm American Physical Society - J. J. Sakurai Prize Winners] ==References== {{Reflist|35em}} {{FRS 2009}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ellis, Richard Keith}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British physicists]] [[Category:People associated with CERN]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Physical Society]] [[Category:J. J. Sakurai Prize for Theoretical Particle Physics recipients]] [[Category:Theoretical physicists]] [[Category:People associated with Fermilab]] [[Category:Academics of Durham University]] {{physicist-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox software | name = SPEDAS | logo = | screenshot = Spedas overview.PNG | caption = The main window of SPEDAS | collapsible = | author = | developer = | released = {{Start date|2014|08|29|df=yes/no}} | discontinued = | latest_release_version = 1.00 | latest_release_date = {{Start date and age|2014|08|29|df=yes/no}} | latest preview version = nightly builds | latest preview date = | programming language = [[IDL (programming language)|IDL]] | operating system = [[Cross-platform]] | platform = | size = 13 MB (compressed) | language = | status = Active | genre = [[Scientific software]] | license = | website = {{URL|wiki.spedas.org}} }}
SPEDAS ('''S'''pace '''P'''hysics '''E'''nvironment '''D'''ata '''A'''nalysis '''S'''oftware) is an open-source data analysis tool intended for [[Space physics|Space Physics]] users. It was developed using [[Interactive Data Language]] (IDL).
== Overview ==
SPEDAS is free software that can download and manipulate data from scientific space missions. It contains both a GUI (Graphical User Interface) and a command line mode for advanced users. It offers various tools for performing calculations and transformations of the data and for visualizing the results. Software modules can be developed for SPEDAS, extending its capabilities. It also includes a tool for downloading data from NASA servers using [http://cdaweb.gsfc.nasa.gov/about.html CDAWeb].
SPEDAS evolved from software developed for the [[THEMIS]] mission, which was called TDAS (THEMIS Data Analysis Software). In turn, TDAS used IDL code developed previously for earlier missions going back to the 1990s.
SPEDAS was developed by scientists and programmers of the [[University of California, Berkeley|UC Berkeley]]'s [[Space Sciences Laboratory]], [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]]'s [http://www.igpp.ucla.edu IGPP] and other contributors.
== Deployment ==
Three different types of SPEDAS deployment are available:
* '''Source code'''. The full IDL code for SPEDAS is available as a zip file download. To use this, users must install and license IDL from [[Exelis Inc.|Exelis]]. * '''Save file'''. IDL save files can run in a free but restricted version of IDL, called IDL Virtual Machine (VM). Users have to download IDL VM from Exelis, install it and register with Exelis before they can use the SPEDAS save file. * '''Executable file'''. This distribution contains executable files for Windows, Linux and Mac OS. In this case, users do not have to separately install and download anything else.
== Plugins ==
One of the main goals of SPEDAS is to accommodate the needs of different NASA missions. Towards this goal, its architecture is modular. Users can develop plugins for loading data, for configuration and for specialized calculations or operations on the data.
Version 1.00 of SPEDAS includes plugins for loading data from the following missions or data sets: * [[THEMIS]] * [[Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite|GOES]] * [[WIND (spacecraft)|WIND]] * [[Advanced Composition Explorer|ACE]] * IUGONET * [[Exploration of Energization and Radiation in Geospace|ERG]] * OMNI * Geomagnetic/Solar indices
Plugins for specialized calculations are: * Generation of GOES overview plots * Generation of THEMIS overview plots * THEMIS particle distribution slices
== External links == * [http://wiki.spedas.org SPEDAS wiki page]
[[Category:Free software]] [[Category:Cross-platform software]] [[Category:Space science]] [[Category:Space physics]]

revision.text:
{{coord|59.97|N|30.324|E|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Image:Botanical_Garden_V.L._Komarov_Botanical_Institute.jpg|thumb|250px|Greenhouse No. 28 at the Saint Petersburg Botanical Garden]] [[Image:Opuntia leucotricha (general view) 02.JPG|thumb|250px|''Opuntia leucotricha'']]
The '''Saint Petersburg Botanical Garden''', also known as the '''Botanic Gardens of the Komarov Botanical Institute''' or the '''Komarov Botanical Garden''', is the oldest [[botanical garden]] in [[Russia]].{{citation needed|date=February 2013}} It consists of outdoor and indoor collections situated on [[Aptekarsky Island]] in [[Saint Petersburg]] and belongs to the [[Komarov Botanical Institute]] of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]]. It is 18.9 [[hectare|ha]] in area, and is bordered by Aptekarsky Prospekt (main entrance), Prof. Popov Street (second entrance), as well as the embankments of the [[Karpovka]] and [[Bolshaya Neva]] rivers.
==Overview== The garden was founded by [[Peter I of Russia|Peter I]] in 1714 as a [[herb garden]] in order to grow [[Herbalism|medicinal plants]] and re-established as a botanical institution under the name Imperial Botanical Garden in 1823. [[Ivan Lepyokhin]] was in charge of the botanical garden from 1774 until 1802. Beginning in 1855, [[Eduard August von Regel]] was associated with the garden, first as Scientific Director and then as Director General (1875-1892). Regel had a particular fascination with the genus ''[[Allium]]'', overseeing collections of these plants in the [[Russian Far East]] and writing about them in two monographs. More than 60 of the alliums he identified bear his name, e.g., ''A. giganteum'' Regel and ''A. rosenbahianum'' Regel.<ref name=Block2010>{{cite book|author=Block, E.|title=Garlic and Other Alliums: The Lore and the Science|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6AB89RHV9ucC&printsec=frontcover|publisher=Royal Society of Chemistry|year=2010|isbn=0-85404-190-7}}</ref> Many alliums can be viewed in the Northern Yard of the garden. In 1897, ''Konstantin George Alexander Winkler''(14 June 1848 - 3 February 1900), became head botanist at the Garden. He then reorganized the herbaria and greenhouse collections.<ref>Walther Killy (editor){{Google books|1NVRfl4gCw0C| Dictionary of German Biography Thibaut - Zycha, Volume 10|page=555}}</ref> Around 1900, [[Boris Fedtschenko]] became head botanist and he organised investigations of various Russian regions including Siberia, Caucusus, Middle Asia and Asiatic Russia. All published in various volumes and books.<ref name=jstor>{{cite web|title=Fedtschenko, Boris Alexjewitsch (Alexeevich) (1872-1947) |date= |url=http://plants.jstor.org/person/bm000331113 | publisher= plants.jstor.org | accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref><ref> David G. Frodin {{Google book|aMjXCF4rmDUC| Guide to Standard Floras of the World: An Annotated, Geographically Arranged |page=658}}</ref>
In 1930, the garden became subordinate to the [[Academy of Sciences of the Soviet Union]] and, in 1931, was merged with the Botanical Museum into the [[Komarov Botanical Institute|Botanical Institute]].
===Greenhouses=== The garden has 25 greenhouses constructed in 1823-1824. They are numbered from 1 to 28 (No. 5 and No. 25 don't exist; No. 10 and No. 11 are shared). Some of them are open to the public (guided visits only), including the large collections of [[azalea]]s and other [[Ericaceae]] (No. 6), [[fern]]s (No. 15), [[cacti]] and other [[succulent]]s (No. 16), various tropical plants (No. 18), the 23.5 m high Big Palm Greenhouse with an important collection of [[orchids]] (No. 26) and the greenhouse with a pond containing ''[[Victoria amazonica]]'' (no. 28). The night blossom of cactus ''[[Selenicereus grandiflorus]]'', cultivated there since 1857, is a celebrated event announced in mass media and open to the public in the 16th greenhouse in June-July. The indoor collections suffered significant losses during the [[Siege of Leningrad]] in 1941-1944; out of 6367 species only 861 survived.
The chain of greenhouses encircles the Southern Yard and the Northern Yard, the latter featuring an extensive outdoor collection of [[Iridaceae]] and [[Ornamental bulbous plant|bulbous]] plants, including many species of ''Allium''. The building of the botanical museum faces the Northern Yard in place of the non-existent greenhouse No. 5.
===Park=== The outer park includes a small rock garden (constructed in the end of the 19th century) located in front of the Big Palm Greenhouse, and a 0.16 km² arboretum, organized partly as an [[English garden]] and partly as a [[formal garden]]. The park, unlike the greenhouses, is closed for visitors from October 1 to May 8. It is elevated only 1.5-3 m above sea-level and has thus regularly suffered from [[floods in Saint Petersburg|catastrophic floods]] characteristic of Saint Petersburg. The herbarium edifice built in 1913 stands in front of the main entrance.
== Images == [[Image:Northern_Yard_St._Petersburg_Botanical_Gardens.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Northern Yard, Saint Petersburg Botanical Garden with greenhouses and ''[[Allium]]'' garden]] [[Image:Allium_moly,_Saint_Petersburg_Botanical_Garden_Northern_Yard.jpg|thumb|250px|center|''Allium moly'' in the Northern Yard, Saint Petersburg Botanical Garden]] [[Image:Bust_of_Eduard_Regel,_Saint_Petersburg_Botanical_Garden.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Bust of Eduard Regel in botanical museum, Saint Petersburg Botanical Garden]] [[Image:Botanical_research_laboratory,_Saint_Petersburg_Botanical_Garden.jpg|thumb|280px|center|Botanical research laboratory, Saint Petersburg Botanical Garden]] [[Image:Palm_Greenhouse,_St._Petersburg_Botanical_Garden.jpg|thumb|260px|left|Palm Greenhouse, St. Petersburg Botanical Garden]] [[Image:Saint_Petersburg_botanical_garden_museum.jpg|thumb|300px|center|Saint Petersburg botanical museum and herbarium building]] {{-}}

Leningrad: Lenizdat, 1989. *Соколов В.С., А.А. Федорова. Ботанический институт имени В. Л. Комарова Академии наук СССР. Leningrad, 1947. *От аптекарского огорода до Ботанического института. Leningrad: Изд-во АН СССР, 1957. *BGCI: [http://www.bgci.org/worldwide/article/0015/ Arboretum of Komarov Botanical Institute in Saint Petersburg, Russia]

{{Orphan|date=May 2010}}
'''Science Theatre''' is an [[undergraduate student]]-run [[science outreach]] organization at [[Michigan State University]]'s [[East Lansing]] campus. Science Theatre visits schools and events throughout [[Michigan]] performing interactive science demonstrations for [[K-12]] students on-stage or up-close. Science Theatre performers are undergraduate and [[graduate student]] volunteers and all performances are made free of charge.
The group's performances consist of arrangements from its catalog of more than seventy demonstrations in biology, chemistry, and physics. Additionally, Science Theatre performs comprehensive shows in [[Astronomy]], [[Environmental science]], [[Pressure]], the [[Periodic Table]], [[Quantum Mechanics]], and [[FRIB]]-related science.
Science Theatre was founded in April 1991 under a grant from the [[National Science Foundation]] and received the 1993 [[American Association for the Advancement of Science|AAAS]] Award for Public Understanding of Science and Technology. Science Theatre is a four-time winner of the Outreach Award from the Michigan State University Department of Physics and Astronomy.
==External links== * [http://sciencetheatre.org/ MSU Science Theatre Official Webpage] * [http://archives.aaas.org/people.php?p_id=344 1993 AAAS Award for Public Understanding of Science and Technology] * [http://statenews.com/index.php/article/2009/02/msu_celebrates_darwins_200th 2 February 2009] [[State News]] coverage * [http://www.uppermichiganssource.com/news/news_story.aspx?id=271491 10 March 2009] [[Fox TV]] coverage * [http://www.dailypress.net/page/content.detail/id/510824.html 11 March 2009] [[Daily Press (Michigan)]] coverage * [http://www.capitalgainsmedia.com/innovationnews/nails0323.aspx 10 June 2009] Capital Gains Coverage
{{Michigan State University}}
[[Category:Student organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Science in society]]

A '''star clock''' (or '''[[nocturnal (instrument)|nocturnal]]''') is a method of using the [[star]]s to determine the [[time]]. This is accomplished by measuring the [[Big Dipper]]'s position in the sky based on a standard clock, and then employing simple addition and subtraction. This method requires no tools; others use an [[astrolabe]] and a [[planisphere]].
A clock's regulator can be adjusted so that it keeps the Mean Sidereal Time rate. When it is then set to an observer's Local Mean Sidereal Time then a star will transit the meridian (passing directly north or south) at the sidereal time of the star's [[Right Ascension]].
==See also== * [[Sidereal time]]
==External links== * [http://www.johnpratt.com/items/astronomy/telltime.html Telling Time by Sun and Stars] by John P. Pratt * [http://www.inquiry.net/outdoor/night/telling_time.htm Inquiry.net]
[[Category:Time in astronomy]] {{astronomy-stub}}

revision.text:
The GrEEK Campus is the world’s first heritage-driven technology center. Not just a physical platform for entrepreneurs, startups, and SMEs, The GrEEK Campus is a catalyst for innovators, creators and GEEKs and a propeller of new-age startup value hubs. A platform home to aspiring entrepreneurs looking to thrive and grow in collaborative environments. A community built from ground up for creative individuals to meet, exchange, showcase ideas and work together towards homegrown technologies and innovations. Founded Dec 2013, The GrEEK Campus became the fastest growing community of resilient startups, venture capital representation hub and academic collaboration center of The Middle East.   A physical ecosystem designer and developer shaping the tech industry, hosting more than 140 companies, carefully selecting and bringing together the right mix of ecosystem players such as seed companies, angel investors, incubators and accelerators - enabling the evolution of our members towards successful entrepreneurial ventures and startup journeys. Today, THE GrEEK Campus is made up of five office buildings on a total space of 25,000 m2, and hosts regular high-profile technology seminars, conferences, open art exhibitions and music concerts, making it an event destination for the entire ecosystem. The campus is just the beginning of a compelling journey that will feature more campuses across town, inside, and outside of Egypt. == History == {{Infobox university | name = THE GrEEK Campus | native_name = الجريك كامبس | native_name_lang = ar | image = THE GrEEK CAMPUS.jpg | established = 2014 | city = Tahrir Gate: 171 Tahrir Street, Downtown, Cairo
Falaki Gate: 28 Falaki Street, Downtown, Cairo | website = http://www.thegreekcampus.com/ | logo = The GrEEK Campus Logo.jpg | architect = | founder = Ahmed El Alfi{{cite news|title=The GrEEK Campus|url=http://www.madamasr.com/sections/economy/greek-campus|accessdate=25 June 2016|work=[[Mada Masr]]|date=23 November 2013}} | officer_in_charge = Ahmed El Alfi (Founder and Chairman), Mohamed Ashraf (General Manager) | affiliation = [[American University in Cairo]] | type = {{Unbulleted list|University campus,|Technology Park}} }} '''The GrEEK Campus''' is Cairo's first technology and innovation park, offering state-of-the-art office spaces in [[Downtown Cairo|Downtown]] Cairo, [[Egypt]].{{cite news|title=Cairo’s GrEEK Campus Underscores Egypt’s Tech Revolution|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/middleeast/2014/02/18/cairos-greek-campus-underscores-egypts-tech-revolution/|accessdate=25 June 2016|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=18 February 2014}}{{cite web|title=Inside The GrEEk Campus|url=http://womenonwalls.org/greek-campus/|publisher=[[Women on Walls]]|accessdate=25 June 2016|date=3 February 2016}} In 1964, The GrEEK Campus was formed by former president Dr. [[Thomas A. Bartlett]] of the [[American University in Cairo]] (AUC).{{cite book|title=The day we bought the Greek campus Thomas Bartlett, AUC President 1963-69|publisher=[[American University in Cairo]]|url=http://www1.aucegypt.edu/aucmemories/articles/Tom%20Bartlette%20buying%20the%20Greek%20campus%20modified.pdf|accessdate=25 June 2016}} When AUC began its relocation to another larger campus on the outskirts of Cairo - and in the outcome of the events of June 2013 – as the campus was left virtually abandoned since Tahrir 2011, Ahmed El Alfi decided to take over The Greek Campus and bring it back to life - more than it ever has been. The concept and vision for The GrEEK Campus wasn’t just about offering traditional commercial work spaces and offices to businesses. It was more about building a community/an ecosystem from the ground up into a campus for techpreneurs, enthusiasts and creative individuals to meet, exchange and showcase their ideas and work together towards new technology and innovation that would ultimately benefit Egypt and the world. == Foundation == The GrEEK CAMPUS was a part of [[American University in Cairo|American University]] for 50 years. In 2013, former president of AUC [[Lisa Anderson]] signed an agreement with Tahrir Alley Technology Park, a Cairo-based company, who leased the property to run a Technology Park.{{cite news|title=AUC’s Greek campus to be transformed Into Egypt’s first technology park|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/11/17/aucs-greek-campus-to-be-transformed-into-egypts-first-technology-park/|accessdate=25 June 2016|work=[[Daily News Egypt]]|date=17 November 2013}} The concept and vision were crafted by Ahmed El Alfi and the technology park was officially launched in 2014. {{cite news|last1=CNBC.com|first1=Elizabeth MacBride, special to|title=The reason Uber is investing in this hot market|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2015/12/07/the-man-helping-to-create-a-tech-ecosystem-in-egypt.html|accessdate=25 June 2016|work=[[CNBC]]|date=7 December 2015}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cairoscene.com/BusinessAndPolitics/Getting-Us-to-the-GrEEK?M=True|title=Getting Us to the GrEEK|website=Cairo Scene|access-date=2016-05-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160915024247/http://www.cairoscene.com/BusinessAndPolitics/Getting-Us-to-the-GrEEK?M=True|archivedate=2016-09-15|df=}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/15/tahrir-square-tech-park_n_4280590.html|title=Cairo's New Neighbor Is A Mini Silicon Valley|date=2013-11-15|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|access-date=2016-05-14}} The GrEEK CAMPUS offers technologically advanced office spaces and promotes innovation and entrepreneurship.{{cite web|title=AUC’s Greek campus for sale|url=http://world.greekreporter.com/2009/10/03/auc%E2%80%99s-greek-campus-for-sale/|publisher=[[Greek Reporter]]|accessdate=25 June 2016}}{{cite news|title=Upper Egypt’s Young Women Seek Change at Greek Campus|url=http://egyptianstreets.com/2015/10/13/upper-egypts-young-women-seek-change-at-greek-campus/|accessdate=25 June 2016|work=[[Egyptian Streets]]|date=13 October 2015}} == Notable events == * [[Startup Grind]] Google Startup Grind{{cite web|title=Startup Grind Cairo|url=http://www.meetup.com/Startup-Grind-Cairo/events/229640899/|publisher=[[Meetup (website)|Meetup]]|accessdate=25 June 2016}} * Google I/O - Cairo{{cite web|title=Google I/O Extended 2014 Cairo + Shorouk — Google Developers|url=https://developers.google.com/events/6649148973514752/|publisher=[[Google Developers]]|accessdate=25 June 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161003135137/https://developers.google.com/events/6649148973514752/|archivedate=3 October 2016|df=}} * [[Maker Faire Africa|Cairo Maker Fair]], 2011{{cite web|last1=Dougherty|first1=Dale|title=Young Makers on the Rise in Egypt: The Makers of Maker Faire Cairo, Amr Saleh and 1Sheeld, Fab Lab Egypt, Karakeeb Makerspace, Creative Expression, Al-Azhar Park|url=https://medium.com/make-and-maker-faire/young-makers-on-the-rise-in-egypt-3a0c555d08bf#.7tqy79mkj|publisher=[[Medium (website)]]|accessdate=25 June 2016|date=11 April 2016}} * [[Wamda]] Mix N' Mentor, Cairo{{Cite web|url=http://www.wamda.com/2016/02/mix-n-mentor-cairo-2016-marketplace-edition|title=Mix N' Mentor Cairo 2016: Marketplace Edition|work=[[Wamda]]|access-date=2016-05-14}} * [[TED (conference)]] TEDx Cairo Women.{{cite web|title=TEDxCairoWomen : TED (conference)|url=https://www.ted.com/tedx/events/13885|publisher=[[TED (conference)]]|accessdate=25 June 2016}} * Egypt Photo Summit{{cite web|title=Egypt Photo Summit "15|url=http://www.egyptphotosummit.com/|publisher=Ggypt Photo Summit|accessdate=25 June 2016}} * [[EgyCon]] * Rise-up Summit, Egypt{{cite news|last1=MacBride|first1=Elizabeth|title=Why Microsoft, Uber And 500 Startups Went To Downtown Cairo|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/elizabethmacbride/2015/12/13/why-microsoft-uber-and-500-startups-came-to-downtown-cairo/#63ee6f1310fb|accessdate=25 June 2016|work=[[Forbes]]}} * [[Downtown Contemporary Arts Festival D-CAF|D-CAF]] Downtown Contemporary Arts Festival. * U.S. Embassy job fair.{{cite web|title=Press Releases 2016 {{!}} Cairo, Egypt - Embassy of the United States|url=http://egypt.usembassy.gov/pr-022716.html|website=egypt.usembassy.gov|publisher=[[United States Ambassador to Egypt]]|accessdate=25 June __NOTOC__ {{Infobox software | name = VTK | title = | logo = VTKlogo.png | logo size = 100px | logo caption = | logo_alt = | screenshot = <!-- Image name is enough --> | caption = | screenshot_size = | screenshot_alt = | collapsible = | author = | developer = [[Kitware|Kitware Inc.]] | released = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | discontinued = | latest release version = 8.1.1 | latest release date = {{Start date and age|2018|5|14|df=yes}}<ref>https://gitlab.kitware.com/vtk/vtk/tree/v8.1.1</ref> | latest preview version = | latest preview date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | frequently updated = <!-- DO NOT include this parameter unless you know what it does --> | status = | programming language = [[C (programming language)|C]], [[C++]], [[Python (programming language)|Python]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gitlab.kitware.com/vtk/vtk|title=Kitware / VTK - GitLab}}</ref> | operating system = [[Cross-platform]] | platform = | size = | language = | language count = <!-- DO NOT include this parameter unless you know what it does --> | language footnote = | genre = [[Scientific visualization]] | license = [[BSD licenses|3-Clause BSD]] | alexa = | website = {{URL|https://www.vtk.org/}} | standard = | AsOf = }} The '''Visualization Toolkit''' ('''VTK''') is an [[open-source software|open-source]], freely available software system for [[3D computer graphics]], [[image processing]] and [[Scientific visualization|visualization]]. VTK consists of a [[C++]] class library and several interpreted interface layers including [[Tcl/Tk]], [[Java (programming language)|Java]], and [[Python (programming language)|Python]]. [[Kitware]], whose team created and continues to extend the toolkit, offers professional support and consulting services for VTK. VTK supports a wide variety of visualization algorithms including: [[Scalar (computing)|scalar]], [[Euclidean vector|vector]], [[tensor]], texture, and volumetric methods; and advanced modeling techniques such as: implicit modeling, polygon reduction, mesh smoothing, cutting, contouring, and [[Delaunay triangulation]]. VTK has an extensive [[information visualization]] framework, has a suite of 3D interaction widgets, supports parallel processing, and integrates with various databases and GUI toolkits such as [[Qt toolkit|Qt]] and [[Tk toolkit|Tk]]. VTK is cross-platform and runs on Linux, Windows, Mac and Unix platforms. At its core VTK is implemented as a C++ toolkit, requiring users to build applications by combining various objects into an application. The system also supports automated wrapping of the C++ core into Python, Java and Tcl, so that VTK applications may also be written using these interpreted programming languages.
VTK is used worldwide in commercial applications, research and development,{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} and is the basis of many advanced visualization applications such as: [[Molekel]], [[ParaView]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paraview.org/|title=Home page of ParaView}}</ref> [[VisIt]], [[VisTrails]], [[MOOSE (software)|MOOSE]], [[3DSlicer]], [[MayaVi]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://code.enthought.com/projects/mayavi/|title=MayaVi Homepage}}</ref> and [[OsiriX]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.osirix-viewer.com/AboutOsiriX.html|title=OsiriX- About}}</ref>
VTK is an open-source toolkit licensed under the [[BSD licenses|BSD license]].
==History== VTK was initially created in 1993 as companion software to the book ''"The Visualization Toolkit: An Object-Oriented Approach to 3D Graphics"'' published by Prentice-Hall. The book and software were written by three researchers (Will Schroeder, Ken Martin and Bill Lorensen) on their own time and with permission from GE (thus the ownership of the software resided with, and continues to reside with, the authors). After the core of VTK was written, users and developers around the world began to improve and apply the system to real-world problems. In particular, GE Medical Systems and other GE businesses graciously contributed to the system. Some researchers, such as Penny Rheinghans began to teach with the book. Other early supporters included Jim Ahrens at Los Alamos National Labs, and unnamed, but generous oil and gas supporters. In recent years, [[Sandia National Labs]] have been strong supporters and co-developers with particular focus on adding information visualization to VTK.
To support what was becoming a large, active and worldwide VTK community Ken and Will, along with Lisa Avila, Charles Law and Bill Hoffman left GE Research to found [[Kitware|Kitware Inc.]] in 1998. Since that time, hundreds of additional developers have created what is now the premier visualization system in the world today.
With the founding of [[Kitware]], the VTK community grew rapidly, and toolkit usage expanded into academic, research and commercial applications. For example, VTK forms the core of the [[3DSlicer]] biomedical computing application, and numerous research papers at IEEE Visualization and other conferences based on VTK have appeared. VTK has been used on a large 1024-processor computer at the [[Los Alamos National Laboratory]] to process nearly a [[Petabyte]] of data. In 2005, [[ParaView]] (based on VTK) was used for [[real-time rendering]] of a [[ZSU-23-4]] Russian Anti-Aircraft vehicle being hit by a planar wave, with 2.5 billion cell calculation, in the [[United States Army Research Laboratory]]. VTK also forms the basis of several collaborations between Kitware and national organizations such as Sandia, Los Alamos, and [[Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory|Livermore National Labs]], who are using VTK as the foundation for their large data visualization needs.
VTK is also one of the key computing tools for the recently established [[National Alliance for Medical Image Computing]], NA-MIC ({{URL|http://www.na-mic.org/}}), part of [[NIH]]'s roadmap initiative for future computing tools.
Recently work on VTK includes a significant expansion of the toolkit to support the ingestion, processing and display of [[informatics]] data. This work is supported by [[Sandia National Laboratories]] under the 'Titan' project and represents one of the first concentrated efforts to unify scientific visualization with informatics functionality.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sandia.gov/Titan|title=Sandia Titan webpage|access-date=2008-11-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090213165439/http://www.sandia.gov/Titan/|archive-date=2009-02-13|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Free software}} * [[Scientific visualization]] * [[Insight Segmentation and Registration Toolkit|ITK]] * [[MeVisLab]] * [[ParaView]] * [[VisIt]]
==Further reading== *{{citation |title=The Visualization Toolkit |last1=Schroeder |first1=Will |last2=Martin |first2=Ken |last3=Lorensen |first3=Bill |isbn=978-1-930934-19-1 |year=2006 |publisher=Kitware |edition=4th}} *{{citation |title=The VTK User's Guide |edition=11th |year=2010 |isbn=978-1-930934-23-8 |publisher=Kitware |last=Avila |first=Lisa Sobierajski}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links==
===Kitware=== * [http://www.kitware.com/ Kitware] * [http://www.itk.org/ Insight Segmentation and Registration toolkit (ITK)] and official [http://www.itk.org/Wiki/ITK ITK Wiki] * [http://www.vtk.org/ Visualization toolkit (VTK)] and official [http://www.vtk.org/Wiki/VTK VTK Wiki] * [http://www.paraview.org/ Parallel Visualization Application (ParaView)] and official [http://www.paraview.org/Wiki/ParaView ParaView Wiki] * [http://www.vtk.org/img/dioot.pdf PDF 9-page technical paper] (with color images) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100110122554/http://www.vtk.org/VTK/project/technical.html A summary of VTK technical features] * [http://www.vtk.org/Wiki/VTK/Examples Over 500 compilable examples on the VTK Examples Wiki] * [http://www.vtk.org/documentation/ Documentation] * [http://www.vtk.org/Wiki/VTK_FAQ FAQ] * [http://www.vtk.org/mailing-lists/ mailing lists] * [https://kitware.github.io/vtk-js/docs/ vtk.js, a Javascript implementation of VTK]
